Copied!

> <span key="71c85ea518314acdb704d10f4746de03"><span offset-key="71c85ea518314acdb704d10f4746de03:0">Note:Your bundles will end up looking a lot different than this.</span></span>

<span key="c7dc42b20a534af2842ad2e5a400b00f"><span offset-key="c7dc42b20a534af2842ad2e5a400b00f:0">If you’re using </span></span><a href="https://create-react-app.dev" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="95ac83e28dfa4097af7d6caa381fef22" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="edeafecb43c44d068722d685c4aee36f"><span data-offset-key="edeafecb43c44d068722d685c4aee36f:0">Create React App</span></span></span></a><span key="f3cd3a6d4be0434ba51294bf2369a59e"><span offset-key="f3cd3a6d4be0434ba51294bf2369a59e:0">, </span></span><a href="https://nextjs.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f1d0fe41e9834888bc8b2f528bd97fc5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="f877d84b7de64944b7fb4176ef949fc0"><span data-offset-key="f877d84b7de64944b7fb4176ef949fc0:0">Next.js</span></span></span></a><span key="abf5a6ed89234fec9501977d0e62385c"><span offset-key="abf5a6ed89234fec9501977d0e62385c:0">, </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="30ecd63505ae4c8c9a9fd99f99a2d771" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="169af5f87fec473988548af1eec68190"><span data-offset-key="169af5f87fec473988548af1eec68190:0">Gatsby</span></span></span></a><span key="e20b2d40d8c44f29a8e8cb6255c4a240"><span offset-key="e20b2d40d8c44f29a8e8cb6255c4a240:0">, or a similar tool, you will have a Webpack setup out of the box to bundle your app.</span></span>

<span key="86c8b58eab1540deb3590de044648254"><span offset-key="86c8b58eab1540deb3590de044648254:0">If you aren’t, you’ll need to set up bundling yourself. For example, see the </span></span><a href="https://webpack.js.org/guides/installation/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a78f5f0783d24995b66e704d76abfdb0" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="68e85809f32341e484f9f08f16617d2d"><span data-offset-key="68e85809f32341e484f9f08f16617d2d:0">Installation</span></span></span></a><span key="cd38dd6a673b49ce87e1e2166586896b"><span offset-key="cd38dd6a673b49ce87e1e2166586896b:0"> and </span></span><a href="https://webpack.js.org/guides/getting-started/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f20a1319fab04ba4af16b008560b0420" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="7fa2d8796d914c0895cee961241dda5e"><span data-offset-key="7fa2d8796d914c0895cee961241dda5e:0">Getting Started</span></span></span></a><span key="585ce3ed12944dc08a6c77a42d3c0a18"><span offset-key="585ce3ed12944dc08a6c77a42d3c0a18:0"> guides on the Webpack docs.</span></span>

# 

<span key="0b95a49767dc4251ab3dd9de24044ea3"><span offset-key="0b95a49767dc4251ab3dd9de24044ea3:0">Code Splitting</span></span>

<span key="973f39c2c53345ef9c84799f3d74478c"><span offset-key="973f39c2c53345ef9c84799f3d74478c:0">Bundling is great, but as your app grows, your bundle will grow too. Especially if you are including large third-party libraries. You need to keep an eye on the code you are including in your bundle so that you don’t accidentally make it so large that your app takes a long time to load.</span></span>

<span key="4f557a07b6e8441a88aedf7cc25b0350"><span offset-key="4f557a07b6e8441a88aedf7cc25b0350:0">To avoid winding up with a large bundle, it’s good to get ahead of the problem and start “splitting” your bundle. Code-Splitting is a feature supported by bundlers like </span></span><a href="https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="347ff6aabbe44f678c0f7c258a8f6af2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="1ba7a2d4da094ad7ae1380efb1f1312f"><span data-offset-key="1ba7a2d4da094ad7ae1380efb1f1312f:0">Webpack</span></span></span></a><span key="5dbe15a54ee249eb83dedc081ea61d5b"><span offset-key="5dbe15a54ee249eb83dedc081ea61d5b:0">, </span></span><a href="https://rollupjs.org/guide/en/#code-splitting" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="92ffc072ef90464a8e5b59bcbeb7098b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="3266c4e31bd74301932324a21b689a74"><span data-offset-key="3266c4e31bd74301932324a21b689a74:0">Rollup</span></span></span></a><span key="d0d1ef60389740e8a7140b4593a11096"><span offset-key="d0d1ef60389740e8a7140b4593a11096:0"> and Browserify (via </span></span><a href="https://github.com/browserify/factor-bundle" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2369bbb3e8214476899f781bd5881e0f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="b5faf9f7694542b98442174a399e03e1"><span data-offset-key="b5faf9f7694542b98442174a399e03e1:0">factor-bundle</span></span></span></a><span key="d92c2d846c7a4b9a9ae1c8ddf4b71d6c"><span offset-key="d92c2d846c7a4b9a9ae1c8ddf4b71d6c:0">) which can create multiple bundles that can be dynamically loaded at runtime.</span></span>

<span key="da71a367c2d149dfbe417d7197af7a44"><span offset-key="da71a367c2d149dfbe417d7197af7a44:0">Code-splitting your app can help you “lazy-load” just the things that are currently needed by the user, which can dramatically improve the performance of your app. While you haven’t reduced the overall amount of code in your app, you’ve avoided loading code that the user may never need, and reduced the amount of code needed during the initial load.</span></span>

# 

<span key="a4da5b7f8f1145398b226a7e2268b4f1">`import()`</span>

<span key="760260f22c4744558d893baffb790399"><span offset-key="760260f22c4744558d893baffb790399:0">The best way to introduce code-splitting into your app is through the dynamic </span>`import()`<span offset-key="760260f22c4744558d893baffb790399:2"> syntax.</span></span>

<span key="95f4f4234d1842e2924522f011f9daa2">**Before:**</span>

1

<span key="3293f9b912884c4db948d7001a8d5e9c"><span offset-key="3293f9b912884c4db948d7001a8d5e9c:0">import { add } from './math';</span></span>

2

<span key="2987c103bbea43efb6e1b8e18b65f245"><span offset-key="2987c103bbea43efb6e1b8e18b65f245:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="130fcb5d0f2440258260f974dd27bd9e"><span offset-key="130fcb5d0f2440258260f974dd27bd9e:0">console.log(add(16, 26));</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e61fa6eb334445509d04943d3849960b">**After:**</span>

1

<span key="e943854767fa431787a0eea596d84c6b"><span offset-key="e943854767fa431787a0eea596d84c6b:0">import("./math").then(math => {</span></span>

2

<span key="882bbae8dda0475a9e10af3940435127"><span offset-key="882bbae8dda0475a9e10af3940435127:0"> console.log(math.add(16, 26));</span></span>

3

<span key="f0bd8ffbf9524c5fa5ec35407267a0d6"><span offset-key="f0bd8ffbf9524c5fa5ec35407267a0d6:0">});</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="bd29121ff94c4b48a2ccfb4c2a35b9b7"><span offset-key="bd29121ff94c4b48a2ccfb4c2a35b9b7:0">When Webpack comes across this syntax, it automatically starts code-splitting your app. If you’re using Create React App, this is already configured for you and you can </span></span><a href="https://create-react-app.dev/docs/code-splitting/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="06bdb8d038854aa8b293a4f41bcd9083" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="d7a8c191643c4234b917911f0c80d041"><span data-offset-key="d7a8c191643c4234b917911f0c80d041:0">start using it</span></span></span></a><span key="662a988a7ec643c3acf15e02c2e97cf0"><span offset-key="662a988a7ec643c3acf15e02c2e97cf0:0"> immediately. It’s also supported out of the box in </span></span><a href="https://nextjs.org/docs/advanced-features/dynamic-import" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="1297069a98114166ac914a2891ebd3d7" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="730f735626cc4a6aa2854fb03f293303"><span data-offset-key="730f735626cc4a6aa2854fb03f293303:0">Next.js</span></span></span></a><span key="b9c8ab1be1684017862e2bb39c3a682d"><span offset-key="b9c8ab1be1684017862e2bb39c3a682d:0">.</span></span>

<span key="b39d4894949748af9fe71c5f72d42a65"><span offset-key="b39d4894949748af9fe71c5f72d42a65:0">If you’re setting up Webpack yourself, you’ll probably want to read Webpack’s </span></span><a href="https://webpack.js.org/guides/code-splitting/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b0b66b9ebabd466b8d685492ee3a4e20" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="267ca998b3d34137820ae981cb74c353"><span data-offset-key="267ca998b3d34137820ae981cb74c353:0">guide on code splitting</span></span></span></a><span key="d736bf7d3805477f9249629c1660d1e0"><span offset-key="d736bf7d3805477f9249629c1660d1e0:0">. Your Webpack config should look vaguely </span></span><a href="https://www.notion.so/ca6e803f5c604d37468b0091d9959269" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="08a70180f65046d396ae2783807086d8" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="9ab46a31ce8447069c5ed3f6f2521783"><span data-offset-key="9ab46a31ce8447069c5ed3f6f2521783:0">like this</span></span></span></a><span key="aa03c80bd09e492aa947cc7638fc971c"><span offset-key="aa03c80bd09e492aa947cc7638fc971c:0">.</span></span>

<span key="6b4585fc4869421c88266ad0fc3231c2"><span offset-key="6b4585fc4869421c88266ad0fc3231c2:0">When using </span></span><a href="https://babeljs.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c785ec77dde04fb4981c1e036fdc3b81" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="35d0536464054c80813d6cc6428e1a30"><span data-offset-key="35d0536464054c80813d6cc6428e1a30:0">Babel</span></span></span></a><span key="6174a081fa9a48bd85e60187d3079f84"><span offset-key="6174a081fa9a48bd85e60187d3079f84:0">, you’ll need to make sure that Babel can parse the dynamic import syntax but is not transforming it. For that you will need </span></span><a href="https://classic.yarnpkg.com/en/package/@babel/plugin-syntax-dynamic-import" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="fcd2c5db662b41a0ae140ee0fabad1f4" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="ab9def4fc7fe426da87787dcbfa93718"><span data-offset-key="ab9def4fc7fe426da87787dcbfa93718:0">@babel/plugin-syntax-dynamic-import</span></span></span></a><span key="848c5316b5a34d92afac64884f3bf536"><span offset-key="848c5316b5a34d92afac64884f3bf536:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="3a9180d6cbe946b499f88ca51f61aee4">`React.lazy`</span>

> <span key="61d7e945b570429798fa461d596edc31"><span offset-key="61d7e945b570429798fa461d596edc31:0">Note:React.lazy and Suspense are not yet available for server-side rendering. If you want to do code-splitting in a server rendered app, we recommend Loadable Components. It has a nice guide for bundle splitting with server-side rendering.</span></span>

<span key="2bc85b1dd4f64e36bdd603345663c278"><span offset-key="2bc85b1dd4f64e36bdd603345663c278:0">The </span>`React.lazy`<span offset-key="2bc85b1dd4f64e36bdd603345663c278:2"> function lets you render a dynamic import as a regular component.</span></span>

<span key="e3393275805d4e7ba8868b83f76d2b76">**Before:**</span>

1

<span key="29d7913a9ffe49558ce6300def41b007"><span offset-key="29d7913a9ffe49558ce6300def41b007:0">import OtherComponent from './OtherComponent';</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="84ae48eae2044b099a03b775b7dca754">**After:**</span>

1

<span key="a6cf31a5b50d4236b431ad679d1801de"><span offset-key="a6cf31a5b50d4236b431ad679d1801de:0">const OtherComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./OtherComponent'));</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="19ef023559044bbc9c0933a2e26ef279"><span offset-key="19ef023559044bbc9c0933a2e26ef279:0">This will automatically load the bundle containing the </span>`OtherComponent`<span offset-key="19ef023559044bbc9c0933a2e26ef279:2"> when this component is first rendered.</span></span>

<span key="f90f446dac9947f09e0f02876e77134a">`React.lazy`<span offset-key="f90f446dac9947f09e0f02876e77134a:1"> takes a function that must call a dynamic </span>`import()`<span offset-key="f90f446dac9947f09e0f02876e77134a:3">. This must return a </span>`Promise`<span offset-key="f90f446dac9947f09e0f02876e77134a:5"> which resolves to a module with a </span>`default`<span offset-key="f90f446dac9947f09e0f02876e77134a:7"> export containing a React component.</span></span>

<span key="418e1a4fa3fa4394a7d0997fdbca7bd9"><span offset-key="418e1a4fa3fa4394a7d0997fdbca7bd9:0">The lazy component should then be rendered inside a </span>`Suspense`<span offset-key="418e1a4fa3fa4394a7d0997fdbca7bd9:2"> component, which allows us to show some fallback content (such as a loading indicator) while we’re waiting for the lazy component to load.</span></span>

1

<span key="0c86a6b8e80c4dc7b6ae742bf70c836b"><span offset-key="0c86a6b8e80c4dc7b6ae742bf70c836b:0">import React, { Suspense } from 'react';</span></span>

2

<span key="6ef97b37757d4761811ddafcb28bab7f"><span offset-key="6ef97b37757d4761811ddafcb28bab7f:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="3c9860ce532e437db694ae29972ed454"><span offset-key="3c9860ce532e437db694ae29972ed454:0"> return (</span></span>

<span key="3a1c13aa199d4b5aaa7dc973f7302aa6"><span offset-key="3a1c13aa199d4b5aaa7dc973f7302aa6:0"> &lt;Suspense fallback={&lt;div>Loading...&lt;/div>}></span></span>

<span key="e32370c257f94f0685f56993bbc3752f"><span offset-key="e32370c257f94f0685f56993bbc3752f:0">The </span>`fallback`<span offset-key="e32370c257f94f0685f56993bbc3752f:2"> prop accepts any React elements that you want to render while waiting for the component to load. You can place the </span>`Suspense`<span offset-key="e32370c257f94f0685f56993bbc3752f:4"> component anywhere above the lazy component. You can even wrap multiple lazy components with a single </span>`Suspense`<span offset-key="e32370c257f94f0685f56993bbc3752f:6"> component.</span></span>

# 

<span key="1c77546997464bfbb4d1c928e437eabc"><span offset-key="1c77546997464bfbb4d1c928e437eabc:0">Error boundaries</span></span>

<span key="0277bf69071f4889884b886942dfaf54"><span offset-key="0277bf69071f4889884b886942dfaf54:0">If the other module fails to load (for example, due to network failure), it will trigger an error. You can handle these errors to show a nice user experience and manage recovery with </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/error-boundaries.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7a82159869574dc9b72d0b0273aebfe5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="62b21ce32e2c46a3992a73f53d3b6827"><span data-offset-key="62b21ce32e2c46a3992a73f53d3b6827:0">Error Boundaries</span></span></span></a><span key="cc4ed83fb47f4c369eb4155eb6144c18"><span offset-key="cc4ed83fb47f4c369eb4155eb6144c18:0">. Once you’ve created your Error Boundary, you can use it anywhere above your lazy components to display an error state when there’s a network error.</span></span>

1

<span key="6463f84b60d44ea58bda252ffbc1e688"><span offset-key="6463f84b60d44ea58bda252ffbc1e688:0">import React, { Suspense } from 'react';</span></span>

# 

<span key="bbe7f8661c4f4e6b94cf21658e0c080d"><span offset-key="bbe7f8661c4f4e6b94cf21658e0c080d:0">Route-based code splitting</span></span>

<span key="7be6194e00e24a1d87292481ea4b047a"><span offset-key="7be6194e00e24a1d87292481ea4b047a:0">Deciding where in your app to introduce code splitting can be a bit tricky. You want to make sure you choose places that will split bundles evenly, but won’t disrupt the user experience.</span></span>

<span key="1439c688c9354f27a6f781452f16eac6"><span offset-key="1439c688c9354f27a6f781452f16eac6:0">A good place to start is with routes. Most people on the web are used to page transitions taking some amount of time to load. You also tend to be re-rendering the entire page at once so your users are unlikely to be interacting with other elements on the page at the same time.</span></span>

<span key="ab6166fa96f84d43ba815ebf47724c0f"><span offset-key="ab6166fa96f84d43ba815ebf47724c0f:0">Here’s an example of how to setup route-based code splitting into your app using libraries like </span></span><a href="https://reacttraining.com/react-router/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6086d80bd2f44b64a932d423b7f67e83" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="36afe6361fb5487080fb43100d812473"><span data-offset-key="36afe6361fb5487080fb43100d812473:0">React Router</span></span></span></a><span key="18924fdb5d554b0dbf8a3f22775e1947"><span offset-key="18924fdb5d554b0dbf8a3f22775e1947:0"> with </span>`React.lazy`<span offset-key="18924fdb5d554b0dbf8a3f22775e1947:2">.</span></span>

1

<span key="229c8f4ef3934d14bd2d79aef87be111"><span offset-key="229c8f4ef3934d14bd2d79aef87be111:0">import React, { Suspense, lazy } from 'react';</span></span>

2

<span key="c34ff95b43bc4b0bb3a1084a017db808"><span offset-key="c34ff95b43bc4b0bb3a1084a017db808:0">import { BrowserRouter as Router, Route, Switch } from 'react-router-dom';</span></span>

# 

<span key="dedef59f682645e587417ab1ff5dcce2"><span offset-key="dedef59f682645e587417ab1ff5dcce2:0">Named Exports</span></span>

<span key="4827cae582424b669e63b1bee0e6783f">`React.lazy`<span offset-key="4827cae582424b669e63b1bee0e6783f:1"> currently only supports default exports. If the module you want to import uses named exports, you can create an intermediate module that reexports it as the default. This ensures that tree shaking keeps working and that you don’t pull in unused components.</span></span>

# 

<span key="13fc0f0a0837466fa0b53e58efc2999f">**Context**</span>

# 

<span key="2d7873b0e50f4d7190f9c1e5d6c4dc79"><span offset-key="2d7873b0e50f4d7190f9c1e5d6c4dc79:0">Context provides a way to pass data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level.</span></span>

<span key="289f0af890b14b62855ab1a3b14e41e3"><span offset-key="289f0af890b14b62855ab1a3b14e41e3:0">In a typical React application, data is passed top-down (parent to child) via props, but such usage can be cumbersome for certain types of props (e.g. locale preference, UI theme) that are required by many components within an application. Context provides a way to share values like these between components without having to explicitly pass a prop through every level of the tree.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

        <span key="ce28069a52fd4336b5abffed31196359"><span offset-key="ce28069a52fd4336b5abffed31196359:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html#updating-context-from-a-nested-component" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3c5702059ad4437ebbd59c2f36f53777" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="fe12d5b33aad40d594b1253136230add"><span data-offset-key="fe12d5b33aad40d594b1253136230add:0">Updating Context from a Nested Component</span></span></span></a><span key="e3565339029a42fb8e09d68fd6982983"><span offset-key="e3565339029a42fb8e09d68fd6982983:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

        <span key="d6ff1fe88d9d4b008d7be56d5c26a644"><span offset-key="d6ff1fe88d9d4b008d7be56d5c26a644:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html#consuming-multiple-contexts" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3985ceee0f714cb0a01a6d065197262f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="f367a501bb104793906bf17ba31be16e"><span data-offset-key="f367a501bb104793906bf17ba31be16e:0">Consuming Multiple Contexts</span></span></span></a><span key="29928afd67014dd7a210d990b4868cda"><span offset-key="29928afd67014dd7a210d990b4868cda:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

    <span key="794079a5cbf7476d8cc06fadc877acb6"><span offset-key="794079a5cbf7476d8cc06fadc877acb6:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html#legacy-api" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d0e8f83c1ab948738da864cf46de7898" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="8a85a42fe57a4760825997011482f368"><span data-offset-key="8a85a42fe57a4760825997011482f368:0">Legacy API</span></span></span></a><span key="75f9bbfd27b6463fb874d5ffe27b0d42"><span offset-key="75f9bbfd27b6463fb874d5ffe27b0d42:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

# 

<span key="01f8cbc67ea145eab789bfe618fd0cdb"><span offset-key="01f8cbc67ea145eab789bfe618fd0cdb:0">When to Use Context</span></span>

<span key="f77fffe786f84005a6e8402afdc70a0e"><span offset-key="f77fffe786f84005a6e8402afdc70a0e:0">Context is designed to share data that can be considered “global” for a tree of React components, such as the current authenticated user, theme, or preferred language. For example, in the code below we manually thread through a “theme” prop in order to style the Button component:</span></span>

1

<span key="a0dba64f47b44d69964b2fd138a9383f"><span offset-key="a0dba64f47b44d69964b2fd138a9383f:0">class App extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="c6982c3858f94fd390eabaf6b2e3e377"><span offset-key="c6982c3858f94fd390eabaf6b2e3e377:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="def25cfb22e1428795a70bb08f84c9cb"><span offset-key="def25cfb22e1428795a70bb08f84c9cb:0"> return &lt;Toolbar theme="dark" />;</span></span>

4

<span key="0b5171cf1d5143c482d75a9efdac6da1"><span offset-key="0b5171cf1d5143c482d75a9efdac6da1:0"> }</span></span>

5

<span key="f55d3d4866a14e36881e2f3f8917afa8"><span offset-key="f55d3d4866a14e36881e2f3f8917afa8:0">}</span></span>

6

<span key="cdde597b5258426a9dc9d1d8889bee9b"><span offset-key="cdde597b5258426a9dc9d1d8889bee9b:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

7

<span key="508f5f7b035241d39c229ed91479e471"><span offset-key="508f5f7b035241d39c229ed91479e471:0">function Toolbar(props) {</span></span>

8

<span key="c27764ec387d45ec90d661f21c17a178"><span offset-key="c27764ec387d45ec90d661f21c17a178:0"> // The Toolbar component must take an extra "theme" prop // and pass it to the ThemedButton. This can become painful // if every single button in the app needs to know the theme // because it would have to be passed through all components. return (</span></span>

9

<span key="266438e1850f461fa118f3abdd74ec76"><span offset-key="266438e1850f461fa118f3abdd74ec76:0"> &lt;div> &lt;ThemedButton theme={props.theme} /> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

10

<span key="bf5bddd0c37c468a8b960e77d417f26b"><span offset-key="bf5bddd0c37c468a8b960e77d417f26b:0">}</span></span>

<span key="db00778fe0df478b82239f64725381de"><span offset-key="db00778fe0df478b82239f64725381de:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

12

<span key="a84657d75f0e4148b1f82242c8e55951"><span offset-key="a84657d75f0e4148b1f82242c8e55951:0">class ThemedButton extends React.Component {</span></span>

13

<span key="7b03c1240fce420796e77b100f832e08"><span offset-key="7b03c1240fce420796e77b100f832e08:0"> render() {</span></span>

<span key="1bd143a899d648d09fc983e152a7b3f9"><span offset-key="1bd143a899d648d09fc983e152a7b3f9:0"> return &lt;Button theme={this.props.theme} />;</span></span>

15

<span key="4923e5bcd445440987825031dd5c6039"><span offset-key="4923e5bcd445440987825031dd5c6039:0"> }</span></span>

16

<span key="6905f28b3bf54e4f80924c08d103b938"><span offset-key="6905f28b3bf54e4f80924c08d103b938:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d6329f00d16f4848a115ed89b8136c0a"><span offset-key="d6329f00d16f4848a115ed89b8136c0a:0">Using context, we can avoid passing props through intermediate elements:</span></span>

1

<span key="bd3c5bf72eb54ba4ba466d081285b1ca"><span offset-key="bd3c5bf72eb54ba4ba466d081285b1ca:0">// Context lets us pass a value deep into the component tree// without explicitly threading it through every component.// Create a context for the current theme (with "light" as the default).const ThemeContext = React.createContext('light');class App extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="c370337159444d538d58c727ab038a72"><span offset-key="c370337159444d538d58c727ab038a72:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="fd197b1d3ab4412b8cfdb489eb6fd322"><span offset-key="fd197b1d3ab4412b8cfdb489eb6fd322:0"> // Use a Provider to pass the current theme to the tree below. // Any component can read it, no matter how deep it is. // In this example, we're passing "dark" as the current value. return (</span></span>

4

<span key="84c938c28e90455db593db66b4f00f98"><span offset-key="84c938c28e90455db593db66b4f00f98:0"> &lt;ThemeContext.Provider value="dark"> &lt;Toolbar /> &lt;/ThemeContext.Provider>);</span></span>

5

<span key="f2befb6af3f0496b9c6b342139de8114"><span offset-key="f2befb6af3f0496b9c6b342139de8114:0"> }</span></span>

8

<span key="9774d663361b4760a02a9fe14ab37e2b"><span offset-key="9774d663361b4760a02a9fe14ab37e2b:0">// A component in the middle doesn't have to// pass the theme down explicitly anymore.function Toolbar() {</span></span>

9

<span key="37c6dd43bed843dd91763b2e67b23c45"><span offset-key="37c6dd43bed843dd91763b2e67b23c45:0"> return (</span></span>

10

<span key="b558920fea274c62b236ec482db4adf6"><span offset-key="b558920fea274c62b236ec482db4adf6:0"> &lt;div> &lt;ThemedButton /> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

11

12

<span key="30586d2d575147e9a53b51f713210a37"><span offset-key="30586d2d575147e9a53b51f713210a37:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

14

<span key="530dd16ab81746669f8a3558e251e205"><span offset-key="530dd16ab81746669f8a3558e251e205:0"> // Assign a contextType to read the current theme context. // React will find the closest theme Provider above and use its value. // In this example, the current theme is "dark". static contextType = ThemeContext;</span></span>

<span key="6d9bef80205547a38c80e22503b3ee60"><span offset-key="6d9bef80205547a38c80e22503b3ee60:0"> render() {</span></span>

<span key="50f577de882e462e8c025fcc1237d81e"><span offset-key="50f577de882e462e8c025fcc1237d81e:0"> return &lt;Button theme={this.context} />; }</span></span>

17

<span key="13ffb3b1cebf48b99c66085d7b7bdddb"><span offset-key="13ffb3b1cebf48b99c66085d7b7bdddb:0">}</span></span>

# 

<span key="6f0fd69621274419965f92d921907a01"><span offset-key="6f0fd69621274419965f92d921907a01:0">Before You Use Context</span></span>

<span key="5a70e9c409634ab4885ffc76de56d12f"><span offset-key="5a70e9c409634ab4885ffc76de56d12f:0">Context is primarily used when some data needs to be accessible by </span>*many*<span offset-key="5a70e9c409634ab4885ffc76de56d12f:2"> components at different nesting levels. Apply it sparingly because it makes component reuse more difficult.</span></span>

<span key="7c2fbe5280ea4f989596fa2fba0472f2">**If you only want to avoid passing some props through many levels,** </span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/composition-vs-inheritance.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7c554983ddb047b19c6a6299f9d3955e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="a679d02cf7324bc5802c30d23d8fb7b6"><strong>component composition</strong></span></span></a><span key="c0983808b4424d36b25ab71ae8a83020"> **is often a simpler solution than context.**</span>

<span key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8"><span offset-key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8:0">For example, consider a </span>`Page`<span offset-key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8:2"> component that passes a </span>`user`<span offset-key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8:4"> and </span>`avatarSize`<span offset-key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8:6"> prop several levels down so that deeply nested </span>`Link`<span offset-key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8:8"> and </span>`Avatar`<span offset-key="2a3b0282bf584d13aa8e68d090cf48f8:10"> components can read it:</span></span>

1

<span key="50050f49317549f1b1ed59c4b593fee1"><span offset-key="50050f49317549f1b1ed59c4b593fee1:0">&lt;Page user={user} avatarSize={avatarSize} />// ... which renders ...</span></span>

2

<span key="d0cb6e5d53b345c09828ffec37a38149"><span offset-key="d0cb6e5d53b345c09828ffec37a38149:0">&lt;PageLayout user={user} avatarSize={avatarSize} />// ... which renders ...</span></span>

3

<span key="0032cfcfaa3a45179c331e15e8ebb67a"><span offset-key="0032cfcfaa3a45179c331e15e8ebb67a:0">&lt;NavigationBar user={user} avatarSize={avatarSize} />// ... which renders ...</span></span>

4

<span key="8cd87766d34c422a8edaa7d9c19f5ed7"><span offset-key="8cd87766d34c422a8edaa7d9c19f5ed7:0">&lt;Link href={user.permalink}></span></span>

5

<span key="150fd6bf51594419acf778db025fd525"><span offset-key="150fd6bf51594419acf778db025fd525:0"> &lt;Avatar user={user} size={avatarSize} /></span></span>

6

<span key="1b517f45352b48b1a56e78e2f95d58a4"><span offset-key="1b517f45352b48b1a56e78e2f95d58a4:0">&lt;/Link></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="38d7f3cc4c6f4a42884d8ff1b35abf44"><span offset-key="38d7f3cc4c6f4a42884d8ff1b35abf44:0">It might feel redundant to pass down the </span>`user`<span offset-key="38d7f3cc4c6f4a42884d8ff1b35abf44:2"> and </span>`avatarSize`<span offset-key="38d7f3cc4c6f4a42884d8ff1b35abf44:4"> props through many levels if in the end only the </span>`Avatar`<span offset-key="38d7f3cc4c6f4a42884d8ff1b35abf44:6"> component really needs it. It’s also annoying that whenever the </span>`Avatar`<span offset-key="38d7f3cc4c6f4a42884d8ff1b35abf44:8"> component needs more props from the top, you have to add them at all the intermediate levels too.</span></span>

<span key="d915226b54ec4b288cd82d898b1bed2b"><span offset-key="d915226b54ec4b288cd82d898b1bed2b:0">One way to solve this issue </span>**without context**<span offset-key="d915226b54ec4b288cd82d898b1bed2b:2"> is to </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/composition-vs-inheritance.html#containment" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="8bf0bad3a48e4edfa18a383ee568165f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="05fcf39bf0a64190b764a7406c64a575"><span data-offset-key="05fcf39bf0a64190b764a7406c64a575:0">pass down the </span><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="05fcf39bf0a64190b764a7406c64a575:1">Avatar</code><span data-offset-key="05fcf39bf0a64190b764a7406c64a575:2"> component itself</span></span></span></a><span key="d500ec949e7845409ecb0d2da81f1c55"><span offset-key="d500ec949e7845409ecb0d2da81f1c55:0"> so that the intermediate components don’t need to know about the </span>`user`<span offset-key="d500ec949e7845409ecb0d2da81f1c55:2"> or </span>`avatarSize`<span offset-key="d500ec949e7845409ecb0d2da81f1c55:4"> props:</span></span>

1

<span key="d996e32cef9d457bb6ee776abd60fc80"><span offset-key="d996e32cef9d457bb6ee776abd60fc80:0">function Page(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="000c14b6392f490794be23fa00063bac"><span offset-key="000c14b6392f490794be23fa00063bac:0"> const user = props.user;</span></span>

3

<span key="8383c8d51b4947b08e3859c064e57dee"><span offset-key="8383c8d51b4947b08e3859c064e57dee:0"> const userLink = (</span></span>

4

<span key="9921753f85b4453abdf91abefc485550"><span offset-key="9921753f85b4453abdf91abefc485550:0"> &lt;Link href={user.permalink}></span></span>

5

<span key="bedbd2b8aab24019b5894a68922e235a"><span offset-key="bedbd2b8aab24019b5894a68922e235a:0"> &lt;Avatar user={user} size={props.avatarSize} /></span></span>

6

<span key="f70a33c80c9b4668966426721537642a"><span offset-key="f70a33c80c9b4668966426721537642a:0"> &lt;/Link>);</span></span>

7

<span key="a886809cbbc24fe7a48e9d381e6f057b"><span offset-key="a886809cbbc24fe7a48e9d381e6f057b:0"> return &lt;PageLayout userLink={userLink} />;</span></span>

8

<span key="07dc01ec7b9e4817a1e8a3e069ecc679"><span offset-key="07dc01ec7b9e4817a1e8a3e069ecc679:0">}</span></span>

9

<span key="91a8a9abe86b4a7ca4dc7cbb987c3f47"><span offset-key="91a8a9abe86b4a7ca4dc7cbb987c3f47:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

10

<span key="a05bb59390d943878bb840c9e8008ee1"><span offset-key="a05bb59390d943878bb840c9e8008ee1:0">// Now, we have:</span></span>

11

<span key="094a32b63ba5490fb7920b2dcf949bf1"><span offset-key="094a32b63ba5490fb7920b2dcf949bf1:0">&lt;Page user={user} avatarSize={avatarSize} />// ... which renders ...</span></span>

12

<span key="10816320313841378d2af5b4b0d79e96"><span offset-key="10816320313841378d2af5b4b0d79e96:0">&lt;PageLayout userLink={...} />// ... which renders ...</span></span>

13

<span key="37246a4c6b32411da8c65757fca4442c"><span offset-key="37246a4c6b32411da8c65757fca4442c:0">&lt;NavigationBar userLink={...} />// ... which renders ...</span></span>

14

<span key="125576ab09764b41848e941eb442dd36"><span offset-key="125576ab09764b41848e941eb442dd36:0">{props.userLink}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="066ed97dc81a48cca617322a32c219a5"><span offset-key="066ed97dc81a48cca617322a32c219a5:0">With this change, only the top-most Page component needs to know about the </span>`Link`<span offset-key="066ed97dc81a48cca617322a32c219a5:2"> and </span>`Avatar`<span offset-key="066ed97dc81a48cca617322a32c219a5:4"> components’ use of </span>`user`<span offset-key="066ed97dc81a48cca617322a32c219a5:6"> and </span>`avatarSize`<span offset-key="066ed97dc81a48cca617322a32c219a5:8">.</span></span>

<span key="4e50df6247084295aafd23cbaa26c486"><span offset-key="4e50df6247084295aafd23cbaa26c486:0">This </span>*inversion of control*<span offset-key="4e50df6247084295aafd23cbaa26c486:2"> can make your code cleaner in many cases by reducing the amount of props you need to pass through your application and giving more control to the root components. Such inversion, however, isn’t the right choice in every case; moving more complexity higher in the tree makes those higher-level components more complicated and forces the lower-level components to be more flexible than you may want.</span></span>

<span key="ad83ebc36cfc4d6c8920f73ad6dce196"><span offset-key="ad83ebc36cfc4d6c8920f73ad6dce196:0">You’re not limited to a single child for a component. You may pass multiple children, or even have multiple separate “slots” for children, </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/composition-vs-inheritance.html#containment" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="92adb5e362664374a00f5622de6d4c5a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="dd86281126b0452ba0d1ee24c426ced8"><span data-offset-key="dd86281126b0452ba0d1ee24c426ced8:0">as documented here</span></span></span></a><span key="da4443d171b54e68aebbd2d83cf3e91d"><span offset-key="da4443d171b54e68aebbd2d83cf3e91d:0">:</span></span>

1

<span key="3bfdceed4ec5476eb2cb4132fd0f9d2c"><span offset-key="3bfdceed4ec5476eb2cb4132fd0f9d2c:0">function Page(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="45a157cf099148b1b85b425486cd8a3f"><span offset-key="45a157cf099148b1b85b425486cd8a3f:0"> const user = props.user;</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="40e67b84c55641ada9f8254e69ed1037"><span offset-key="40e67b84c55641ada9f8254e69ed1037:0">This pattern is sufficient for many cases when you need to decouple a child from its immediate parents. You can take it even further with </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/render-props.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="8e9c8dbf26b24b1a878c5557a5e3a8a3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="9824eb09cb9c4ea0b98935be2b91ec93"><span data-offset-key="9824eb09cb9c4ea0b98935be2b91ec93:0">render props</span></span></span></a><span key="5b609867fd054bd6a08fbb8717cb367c"><span offset-key="5b609867fd054bd6a08fbb8717cb367c:0"> if the child needs to communicate with the parent before rendering.</span></span>

<span key="af5f1ead1c954aedb753ae757bfdf6b2"><span offset-key="af5f1ead1c954aedb753ae757bfdf6b2:0">However, sometimes the same data needs to be accessible by many components in the tree, and at different nesting levels. Context lets you “broadcast” such data, and changes to it, to all components below. Common examples where using context might be simpler than the alternatives include managing the current locale, theme, or a data cache.</span></span>

# 

<span key="d29aa857369443509928f1fc9fc80f2a"><span offset-key="d29aa857369443509928f1fc9fc80f2a:0">API</span></span>

# 

<span key="c2ea34ac815b41e4932f25015a459426">`React.createContext`</span>

1

<span key="ee6fa83231274307a683bc7d5df9e1aa"><span offset-key="ee6fa83231274307a683bc7d5df9e1aa:0">const MyContext = React.createContext(defaultValue);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0134780e25e243b5a903b99e98d6e4b6"><span offset-key="0134780e25e243b5a903b99e98d6e4b6:0">Creates a Context object. When React renders a component that subscribes to this Context object it will read the current context value from the closest matching </span>`Provider`<span offset-key="0134780e25e243b5a903b99e98d6e4b6:2"> above it in the tree.</span></span>

<span key="d2f7044712fe4589843969d286fa54ac"><span offset-key="d2f7044712fe4589843969d286fa54ac:0">The </span>`defaultValue`<span offset-key="d2f7044712fe4589843969d286fa54ac:2"> argument is </span>**only**<span offset-key="d2f7044712fe4589843969d286fa54ac:4"> used when a component does not have a matching Provider above it in the tree. This default value can be helpful for testing components in isolation without wrapping them. Note: passing </span>`undefined`<span offset-key="d2f7044712fe4589843969d286fa54ac:6"> as a Provider value does not cause consuming components to use </span>`defaultValue`<span offset-key="d2f7044712fe4589843969d286fa54ac:8">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="290cc6dcdddf43489a72d5496de44f34">`Context.Provider`</span>

1

<span key="5e78a62996874f54b8b99ebcef9a490e"><span offset-key="5e78a62996874f54b8b99ebcef9a490e:0">&lt;MyContext.Provider value={/\* some value \*/}></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b0cacbb2da3f46a2996751e9fa8c68e9"><span offset-key="b0cacbb2da3f46a2996751e9fa8c68e9:0">Every Context object comes with a Provider React component that allows consuming components to subscribe to context changes.</span></span>

<span key="8857f5d45e514f59903bfef835235229"><span offset-key="8857f5d45e514f59903bfef835235229:0">The Provider component accepts a </span>`value`<span offset-key="8857f5d45e514f59903bfef835235229:2"> prop to be passed to consuming components that are descendants of this Provider. One Provider can be connected to many consumers. Providers can be nested to override values deeper within the tree.</span></span>

<span key="7215394afcee49cca51dc3237740b347"><span offset-key="7215394afcee49cca51dc3237740b347:0">All consumers that are descendants of a Provider will re-render whenever the Provider’s </span>`value`<span offset-key="7215394afcee49cca51dc3237740b347:2"> prop changes. The propagation from Provider to its descendant consumers (including </span>`[.contextType](<https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html#classcontexttype>)`<span offset-key="7215394afcee49cca51dc3237740b347:4"> and </span>`[useContext](<https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-reference.html#usecontext>)`<span offset-key="7215394afcee49cca51dc3237740b347:6">) is not subject to the </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="7215394afcee49cca51dc3237740b347:8"> method, so the consumer is updated even when an ancestor component skips an update.</span></span>

<span key="f5aa5bc9399c428bad7f6246242de9af"><span offset-key="f5aa5bc9399c428bad7f6246242de9af:0">Changes are determined by comparing the new and old values using the same algorithm as </span>`[Object.is](<https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/is#Description>)`<span offset-key="f5aa5bc9399c428bad7f6246242de9af:2">.</span></span>

> <span key="0f011167037d46d5b32d5754736fb922"><span offset-key="0f011167037d46d5b32d5754736fb922:0">NoteThe way changes are determined can cause some issues when passing objects as value: see Caveats.</span></span>

<span key="44884427a37a49cc9430fa953850738d"><span offset-key="44884427a37a49cc9430fa953850738d:0">The </span>`contextType`<span offset-key="44884427a37a49cc9430fa953850738d:2"> property on a class can be assigned a Context object created by </span>`[React.createContext()](<https://reactjs.org/docs/context.html#reactcreatecontext>)`<span offset-key="44884427a37a49cc9430fa953850738d:4">. Using this property lets you consume the nearest current value of that Context type using </span>`this.context`<span offset-key="44884427a37a49cc9430fa953850738d:6">. You can reference this in any of the lifecycle methods including the render function.</span></span>

> <span key="98baffacef774f41b460949b0ab02ed6"><span offset-key="98baffacef774f41b460949b0ab02ed6:0">Note:You can only subscribe to a single context using this API. If you need to read more than one see Consuming Multiple Contexts.If you are using the experimental public class fields syntax, you can use a static class field to initialize your contextType.</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="a1e12fb78ca34e13b95e31dec05e77c4"><span offset-key="a1e12fb78ca34e13b95e31dec05e77c4:0">A React component that subscribes to context changes. Using this component lets you subscribe to a context within a </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/components-and-props.html#function-and-class-components" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="31c9f6de19c4423a9af68a81640d6667" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="bfb1b62355d040ad901b490bc9638cfd"><span data-offset-key="bfb1b62355d040ad901b490bc9638cfd:0">function component</span></span></span></a><span key="88fcc12339da404cb53e92b5f5da0fc7"><span offset-key="88fcc12339da404cb53e92b5f5da0fc7:0">.</span></span>

<span key="3c5252a7645343db8c0cfc5fd5345b88"><span offset-key="3c5252a7645343db8c0cfc5fd5345b88:0">Requires a </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/render-props.html#using-props-other-than-render" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a443a6a49f5b4152ba3bc36deec03fc2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="8e60e0e5d9574410ab2d924170c78419"><span data-offset-key="8e60e0e5d9574410ab2d924170c78419:0">function as a child</span></span></span></a><span key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a"><span offset-key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a:0">. The function receives the current context value and returns a React node. The </span>`value`<span offset-key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a:2"> argument passed to the function will be equal to the </span>`value`<span offset-key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a:4"> prop of the closest Provider for this context above in the tree. If there is no Provider for this context above, the </span>`value`<span offset-key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a:6"> argument will be equal to the </span>`defaultValue`<span offset-key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a:8"> that was passed to </span>`createContext()`<span offset-key="60adeedd18fd4b8e93b9d6a1e501308a:10">.</span></span>

> <span key="bf636cb480924adf8657608d8e2cfa1c"><span offset-key="bf636cb480924adf8657608d8e2cfa1c:0">NoteFor more information about the ‘function as a child’ pattern, see render props.</span></span>

# 

<span key="56a17cb79f844c099ab6f31b22fa6954">`Context.displayName`</span>

<span key="060d20d2950e413daa4bf3ab18eb1359"><span offset-key="060d20d2950e413daa4bf3ab18eb1359:0">For example, the following component will appear as MyDisplayName in the DevTools:</span></span>

#

<span key="9ae04075786f426ab15be6747462ef5f"><span offset-key="9ae04075786f426ab15be6747462ef5f:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

<span key="09f9b7fbbb19431db3f4d7193daeed74"><span offset-key="09f9b7fbbb19431db3f4d7193daeed74:0"> // App component that provides initial context values</span></span>

<span key="5fa89fe3cb224329a174df12cf35341f"><span offset-key="5fa89fe3cb224329a174df12cf35341f:0"> return (</span></span>

<span key="4f0168bdd1e94bc4925e5d2f722a5902"><span offset-key="4f0168bdd1e94bc4925e5d2f722a5902:0">If two or more context values are often used together, you might want to consider creating your own render prop component that provides both.</span></span>

# 

<span key="0a24b4b031f3487288c7c4168863fd4a"><span offset-key="0a24b4b031f3487288c7c4168863fd4a:0">Caveats</span></span>

<span key="9f076a17c34344f9a126294820ea38f8"><span offset-key="9f076a17c34344f9a126294820ea38f8:0">Because context uses reference identity to determine when to re-render, there are some gotchas that could trigger unintentional renders in consumers when a provider’s parent re-renders. For example, the code below will re-render all consumers every time the Provider re-renders because a new object is always created for </span>`value`<span offset-key="9f076a17c34344f9a126294820ea38f8:2">:</span></span>

1

<span key="ae2aa890523041b19204764614c71149"><span offset-key="ae2aa890523041b19204764614c71149:0">class App extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="cafd1b5ebb914e2cbb3364050ba64b06"><span offset-key="cafd1b5ebb914e2cbb3364050ba64b06:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="4f35fdde9c404c7e8c8fc97b5a801b78"><span offset-key="4f35fdde9c404c7e8c8fc97b5a801b78:0"> return (</span></span>

4

<span key="63d5342d0f634d589ad5bd5e96517ee3"><span offset-key="63d5342d0f634d589ad5bd5e96517ee3:0"> &lt;MyContext.Provider value={{something: 'something'}}> &lt;Toolbar /> &lt;/MyContext.Provider>);</span></span>

5

<span key="929252a6a9bf46358339dda7bd4f9851"><span offset-key="929252a6a9bf46358339dda7bd4f9851:0"> }</span></span>

6

<span key="442b723217fe43d6af3583f903ae6d36"><span offset-key="442b723217fe43d6af3583f903ae6d36:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9e8a9d8d678147e3be4051e395023540"><span offset-key="9e8a9d8d678147e3be4051e395023540:0">To get around this, lift the value into the parent’s state:</span></span>

1

<span key="aa97344e2e204e5ca1b145381e336cb5"><span offset-key="aa97344e2e204e5ca1b145381e336cb5:0">class App extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="211d62ef67b5424bb650f7b60a139e09"><span offset-key="211d62ef67b5424bb650f7b60a139e09:0"> constructor(props) {</span></span>

3

<span key="827fc3a83e914946ae266e3d25cd4ce5"><span offset-key="827fc3a83e914946ae266e3d25cd4ce5:0"> super(props);</span></span>

4

<span key="aa7e5c15160344a5989df7318ab82eae"><span offset-key="aa7e5c15160344a5989df7318ab82eae:0"> this.state = {</span></span>

5

<span key="f038d0eb20de4043a0f3954e8229b485"><span offset-key="f038d0eb20de4043a0f3954e8229b485:0"> value: {something: 'something'}, };</span></span>

6

<span key="d46fbb2d50d84bd0a63086b9d8d3ceaf"><span offset-key="d46fbb2d50d84bd0a63086b9d8d3ceaf:0"> }</span></span>

7

<span key="3968269bb6df45b782165f68f3b3ddad"><span offset-key="3968269bb6df45b782165f68f3b3ddad:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

8

<span key="0b81fee48f324e0e8a47add8cf791875"><span offset-key="0b81fee48f324e0e8a47add8cf791875:0"> render() {</span></span>

9

<span key="6185afda41ff46fc9ed64a5b7e5d6a3a"><span offset-key="6185afda41ff46fc9ed64a5b7e5d6a3a:0"> return (</span></span>

10

<span key="839c181cbfe24fcf9528ca4b155ff9c6"><span offset-key="839c181cbfe24fcf9528ca4b155ff9c6:0"> &lt;MyContext.Provider value={this.state.value}> &lt;Toolbar /> &lt;/MyContext.Provider>);</span></span>

11

<span key="8a08f9d61e5646ac881302cdeefa8d47"><span offset-key="8a08f9d61e5646ac881302cdeefa8d47:0"> }</span></span>

# 

<span key="a97c5351b6964cccafec9962fa7e4938"><span offset-key="a97c5351b6964cccafec9962fa7e4938:0">Legacy API</span></span>

> <span key="55b3df2001f9468f90e70c68ca396cb2"><span offset-key="55b3df2001f9468f90e70c68ca396cb2:0">NoteReact previously shipped with an experimental context API. The old API will be supported in all 16.x releases, but applications using it should migrate to the new version. The legacy API will be removed in a future major React version. Read the legacy context docs here.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6b9260cd9f454c96986550338823f239">**Fragments**</span>

# 

<span key="4d5e6747ca614e689f22a78d2c2d05bf"><span offset-key="4d5e6747ca614e689f22a78d2c2d05bf:0">A common pattern in React is for a component to return multiple elements. Fragments let you group a list of children without adding extra nodes to the DOM.</span></span>

1

<span key="146176723601400c9d91c639b87b972c"><span offset-key="146176723601400c9d91c639b87b972c:0">render() {</span></span>

2

<span key="682e7cbdf09249998d1ed7b3b319d242"><span offset-key="682e7cbdf09249998d1ed7b3b319d242:0"> return (</span></span>

3

<span key="61f14ad82e8a43489539f3a8ee87f288"><span offset-key="61f14ad82e8a43489539f3a8ee87f288:0"> &lt;React.Fragment></span></span>

4

<span key="fab815416da542979940328030e4d6a5"><span offset-key="fab815416da542979940328030e4d6a5:0"> &lt;ChildA /></span></span>

5

<span key="362fb28dca4a44eaaa073ecce3b2849e"><span offset-key="362fb28dca4a44eaaa073ecce3b2849e:0"> &lt;ChildB /></span></span>

6

<span key="53e4981825064a11b4b2ac2128357fcc"><span offset-key="53e4981825064a11b4b2ac2128357fcc:0"> &lt;ChildC /></span></span>

7

<span key="f02edafa68794c1f8537ffdce640d807"><span offset-key="f02edafa68794c1f8537ffdce640d807:0"> &lt;/React.Fragment>);</span></span>

8

<span key="aabaa21b101f4582b90d12c6458f8783"><span offset-key="aabaa21b101f4582b90d12c6458f8783:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8cec42bd2ce0446fa4512d44fb4c8287"><span offset-key="8cec42bd2ce0446fa4512d44fb4c8287:0">There is also a new </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/fragments.html#short-syntax" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="5ad283dbb5984cbe99f967c9813c09b4" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="de910f57c4ae4d049bc635bb02b862e3"><span data-offset-key="de910f57c4ae4d049bc635bb02b862e3:0">short syntax</span></span></span></a><span key="7de0cd16b3ac4997b12f8a70de301381"><span offset-key="7de0cd16b3ac4997b12f8a70de301381:0"> for declaring them.</span></span>

# 

<span key="15b6e790cd5d48ecb6dce0c0ed9cec67"><span offset-key="15b6e790cd5d48ecb6dce0c0ed9cec67:0">Motivation</span></span>

<span key="9fa2c3603d64473b8220d71a055f796a"><span offset-key="9fa2c3603d64473b8220d71a055f796a:0">A common pattern is for a component to return a list of children. Take this example React snippet:</span></span>

1

<span key="ea18efb9f3ed4278b3026d686857afc5"><span offset-key="ea18efb9f3ed4278b3026d686857afc5:0">class Table extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="c78ebc6d657c43af8d4248a2bddb1073"><span offset-key="c78ebc6d657c43af8d4248a2bddb1073:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="20aea01338fe400486248a91fa0910b1"><span offset-key="20aea01338fe400486248a91fa0910b1:0"> return (</span></span>

4

<span key="34e1a39cfb1a428ba0c1d59a95cb170a"><span offset-key="34e1a39cfb1a428ba0c1d59a95cb170a:0"> &lt;table></span></span>

5

<span key="3b5e00a0c9014e80b1c61ed0a70d47f5"><span offset-key="3b5e00a0c9014e80b1c61ed0a70d47f5:0"> &lt;tr></span></span>

6

<span key="59cbea9800914d178f692d054e391c47"><span offset-key="59cbea9800914d178f692d054e391c47:0"> &lt;Columns /></span></span>

7

<span key="2c1fc8db933045c28d780dc511b5ec52"><span offset-key="2c1fc8db933045c28d780dc511b5ec52:0"> &lt;/tr></span></span>

8

<span key="c98711b4c5614ea4bf502ba098069358"><span offset-key="c98711b4c5614ea4bf502ba098069358:0"> &lt;/table>);</span></span>

9

<span key="0ec9ca6f8f7743638451d3c8129e7d82"><span offset-key="0ec9ca6f8f7743638451d3c8129e7d82:0"> }</span></span>

10

<span key="f87fcf2a3e5e4f7ab54d529549672f1e"><span offset-key="f87fcf2a3e5e4f7ab54d529549672f1e:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a21b5bb66d1c40a1a83ed15e7abb318c">`<Columns />`<span offset-key="a21b5bb66d1c40a1a83ed15e7abb318c:1"> would need to return multiple </span>`<td>`<span offset-key="a21b5bb66d1c40a1a83ed15e7abb318c:3"> elements in order for the rendered HTML to be valid. If a parent div was used inside the </span>`render()`<span offset-key="a21b5bb66d1c40a1a83ed15e7abb318c:5"> of </span>`<Columns />`<span offset-key="a21b5bb66d1c40a1a83ed15e7abb318c:7">, then the resulting HTML will be invalid.</span></span>

1

<span key="5181b7d7ce9c4c3c8b6b5c0cd0b0a18c"><span offset-key="5181b7d7ce9c4c3c8b6b5c0cd0b0a18c:0">class Columns extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="f56d027303a04dba9d8f03454ba71f2c"><span offset-key="f56d027303a04dba9d8f03454ba71f2c:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="2ca57c67209f42d1a66ac47732682d0a"><span offset-key="2ca57c67209f42d1a66ac47732682d0a:0"> return (</span></span>

4

<span key="a7a220b2fe8c43fa87e04db63c590d96"><span offset-key="a7a220b2fe8c43fa87e04db63c590d96:0"> &lt;div></span></span>

5

<span key="680537b0006945b49abbcedf10c74569"><span offset-key="680537b0006945b49abbcedf10c74569:0"> &lt;td>Hello&lt;/td></span></span>

6

<span key="954020cbcece4995a1f0610055ea1d5c"><span offset-key="954020cbcece4995a1f0610055ea1d5c:0"> &lt;td>World&lt;/td></span></span>

7

<span key="1c2ab56dd3f342578d2a90cff3459add"><span offset-key="1c2ab56dd3f342578d2a90cff3459add:0"> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

8

<span key="9d1688a8a8d44bfeb7ab7466b503b2ba"><span offset-key="9d1688a8a8d44bfeb7ab7466b503b2ba:0"> }</span></span>

9

<span key="4feacb290e3d4c148dbed471456998d9"><span offset-key="4feacb290e3d4c148dbed471456998d9:0">}</span></span>

<span key="8f04ff4da3f24304848c63c9960cf53f"><span offset-key="8f04ff4da3f24304848c63c9960cf53f:0">results in a </span>`<Table />`<span offset-key="8f04ff4da3f24304848c63c9960cf53f:2"> output of:</span></span>

1

<span key="398d362c66644195b5426f639211a301"><span offset-key="398d362c66644195b5426f639211a301:0">&lt;table></span></span>

<span key="4b4ed138c8e746248b082d0561944175"><span offset-key="4b4ed138c8e746248b082d0561944175:0"> &lt;tr></span></span>

<span key="d7c922e2fa0c4e86a5377e0f90567095"><span offset-key="d7c922e2fa0c4e86a5377e0f90567095:0"> &lt;div></span></span>

4

<span key="eb2a5507fc334deaa23d90f922934a6c"><span offset-key="eb2a5507fc334deaa23d90f922934a6c:0"> &lt;td>Hello&lt;/td></span></span>

5

<span key="47308b3d608b4b8bb01b30badc1042f3"><span offset-key="47308b3d608b4b8bb01b30badc1042f3:0"> &lt;td>World&lt;/td></span></span>

6

<span key="47009ac284384857bc4b2f1fcadec3f8"><span offset-key="47009ac284384857bc4b2f1fcadec3f8:0"> &lt;/div></span></span>

<span key="abbe1c6df00a467cbbcb2ffe66732074"><span offset-key="abbe1c6df00a467cbbcb2ffe66732074:0"> &lt;/tr></span></span>

<span key="4e941951af374328905e1fd7c7426f0e"><span offset-key="4e941951af374328905e1fd7c7426f0e:0">&lt;/table></span></span>

<span key="c2e8f0c252744ec9a35c5ec02bf97e28"><span offset-key="c2e8f0c252744ec9a35c5ec02bf97e28:0">Fragments solve this problem.</span></span>

# 

<span key="247b9e271e94439bbc782eee705ba275"><span offset-key="247b9e271e94439bbc782eee705ba275:0">Usage</span></span>

<span key="4934471e6a084436b60d47b3f57e773d"><span offset-key="4934471e6a084436b60d47b3f57e773d:0"> &lt;React.Fragment> &lt;td>Hello&lt;/td> &lt;td>World&lt;/td> &lt;/React.Fragment> );</span></span>

# 

<span key="8dbf30cfeea04d3aba41e2397632c97e"><span offset-key="8dbf30cfeea04d3aba41e2397632c97e:0">Short Syntax</span></span>

<span key="3ce69d29f90a4cddb5b6305b890b0da0"><span offset-key="3ce69d29f90a4cddb5b6305b890b0da0:0">There is a new, shorter syntax you can use for declaring fragments. It looks like empty tags:</span></span>

1

<span key="f2472a51bc3849b6b272fa6ecf99dbb4"><span offset-key="f2472a51bc3849b6b272fa6ecf99dbb4:0">class Columns extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="638fb2fc31234682b9ed5ba67c9e8488"><span offset-key="638fb2fc31234682b9ed5ba67c9e8488:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="92cdfffcdc224d0db5ee840b1b4ad2a1"><span offset-key="92cdfffcdc224d0db5ee840b1b4ad2a1:0"> return (</span></span>

4

<span key="5a8a0802c19c4e2bad2ed51a9a1b3718"><span offset-key="5a8a0802c19c4e2bad2ed51a9a1b3718:0"> &lt;&gt; &lt;td>Hello&lt;/td> &lt;td>World&lt;/td> &lt;/> );</span></span>

5

<span key="08bf85bff8114f1eb14fd8d4a0d932dd"><span offset-key="08bf85bff8114f1eb14fd8d4a0d932dd:0"> }</span></span>

<span key="8ffee9f646644e2f9221ba879e19c575"><span offset-key="8ffee9f646644e2f9221ba879e19c575:0">}</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="c59aa555c4af4e96b4ccd39c3f2041dc"><span offset-key="c59aa555c4af4e96b4ccd39c3f2041dc:0">You can use </span>`<></>`<span offset-key="c59aa555c4af4e96b4ccd39c3f2041dc:2"> the same way you’d use any other element except that it doesn’t support keys or attributes.</span></span>

# 

<span key="62118bc4bb9845fc8db31a67b20ad7be"><span offset-key="62118bc4bb9845fc8db31a67b20ad7be:0">Keyed Fragments</span></span>

<span key="206acb26ea4e4f74baa4df05163fd435"><span offset-key="206acb26ea4e4f74baa4df05163fd435:0">Fragments declared with the explicit </span>`<React.Fragment>`<span offset-key="206acb26ea4e4f74baa4df05163fd435:2"> syntax may have keys. A use case for this is mapping a collection to an array of fragments — for example, to create a description list:</span></span>

1

<span key="0dadaddb708945e6a3e2642c967ac177"><span offset-key="0dadaddb708945e6a3e2642c967ac177:0">function Glossary(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="d094455b6a8f46189a7663325eadb3f2"><span offset-key="d094455b6a8f46189a7663325eadb3f2:0"> return (</span></span>

3

<span key="6614c8cd22f8468d95ea57c88ed4d2b3"><span offset-key="6614c8cd22f8468d95ea57c88ed4d2b3:0"> &lt;dl></span></span>

4

<span key="ff7a715ed745434aa542548491748914"><span offset-key="ff7a715ed745434aa542548491748914:0"> {props.items.map(item => (</span></span>

5

<span key="8b28e8406c694b91aa7183ce5c11c569"><span offset-key="8b28e8406c694b91aa7183ce5c11c569:0"> // Without the \`key\`, React will fire a key warning</span></span>

6

<span key="b187643f0d804b459ee969cd115c4c9b"><span offset-key="b187643f0d804b459ee969cd115c4c9b:0"> &lt;React.Fragment key={item.id}></span></span>

7

<span key="acf1de6b50184032acbc3c1f31ea5495"><span offset-key="acf1de6b50184032acbc3c1f31ea5495:0"> &lt;dt>{item.term}&lt;/dt></span></span>

8

<span key="994e22033460466e9fa11a0b1381eb7a"><span offset-key="994e22033460466e9fa11a0b1381eb7a:0"> &lt;dd>{item.description}&lt;/dd></span></span>

9

<span key="83d6b7bee6384e61ad9c08c8dd103b71"><span offset-key="83d6b7bee6384e61ad9c08c8dd103b71:0"> &lt;/React.Fragment>))}</span></span>

10

<span key="603996ee11c64fa184ad60d316d12658"><span offset-key="603996ee11c64fa184ad60d316d12658:0"> &lt;/dl>);</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="73e5c719de2943b08a6f7df3be94d0fe">`key`<span offset-key="73e5c719de2943b08a6f7df3be94d0fe:1"> is the only attribute that can be passed to </span>`Fragment`<span offset-key="73e5c719de2943b08a6f7df3be94d0fe:3">. In the future, we may add support for additional attributes, such as event handlers.</span></span>

# 

<span key="d98a741c1e534b498f133e7b29932365"><span offset-key="d98a741c1e534b498f133e7b29932365:0">Live Demo</span></span>

<span key="cb5155c7bd0b4df5ace600975dcb07d5"><span offset-key="cb5155c7bd0b4df5ace600975dcb07d5:0">You can try out the new JSX fragment syntax with this </span></span><a href="https://codepen.io/reactjs/pen/VrEbjE?editors=1000" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e5c1a35cd1e643ba9bf9c7d38c743a34" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="17b8dd076c5343f092bc97e534ed8f84"><span data-offset-key="17b8dd076c5343f092bc97e534ed8f84:0">CodePen</span></span></span></a><span key="1dced0eba1a6445286c3fb0df5f3d078"><span offset-key="1dced0eba1a6445286c3fb0df5f3d078:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="de979e4c749d4d86bafd46bdbf6db28a">**Higher-Order Components**</span>

# 

<span key="a0bc811221a0424eb00ca400d717b3be"><span offset-key="a0bc811221a0424eb00ca400d717b3be:0">A higher-order component (HOC) is an advanced technique in React for reusing component logic. HOCs are not part of the React API, per se. They are a pattern that emerges from React’s compositional nature.</span></span>

<span key="3b7ba3f55e494a2ab14c3f525e0c9335"><span offset-key="3b7ba3f55e494a2ab14c3f525e0c9335:0">Concretely, </span>**a higher-order component is a function that takes a component and returns a new component.**</span>

<span key="560f0420167741bd9076807cbf841f54">`const EnhancedComponent = higherOrderComponent(WrappedComponent);`</span>

<span key="5984f94e8da34f21b9bd03ad6f647dfc"><span offset-key="5984f94e8da34f21b9bd03ad6f647dfc:0">Whereas a component transforms props into UI, a higher-order component transforms a component into another component.</span></span>

<span key="f603d4c4ba244be4a553ff557c5204cc"><span offset-key="f603d4c4ba244be4a553ff557c5204cc:0">HOCs are common in third-party React libraries, such as Redux’s </span>`[connect](<https://github.com/reduxjs/react-redux/blob/master/docs/api/connect.md#connect>)`<span offset-key="f603d4c4ba244be4a553ff557c5204cc:2"> and Relay’s </span>`[createFragmentContainer](<https://relay.dev/docs/v10.1.3/fragment-container/#createfragmentcontainer>)`<span offset-key="f603d4c4ba244be4a553ff557c5204cc:4">.</span></span>

<span key="ab2d2af94511473c87c7f4801d11c856"><span offset-key="ab2d2af94511473c87c7f4801d11c856:0">In this document, we’ll discuss why higher-order components are useful, and how to write your own.</span></span>

# 

<span key="8de8eadfae094d43b614a2d2705fa101"><span offset-key="8de8eadfae094d43b614a2d2705fa101:0">Use HOCs For Cross-Cutting Concerns</span></span>

> <span key="cf06b3bc5adf419e8445574a90caa04b"><span offset-key="cf06b3bc5adf419e8445574a90caa04b:0">NoteWe previously recommended mixins as a way to handle cross-cutting concerns. We’ve since realized that mixins create more trouble than they are worth. Read more about why we’ve moved away from mixins and how you can transition your existing components.</span></span>

<span key="498a5d42d5d843e0a1475f58d87a55f0"><span offset-key="498a5d42d5d843e0a1475f58d87a55f0:0">Components are the primary unit of code reuse in React. However, you’ll find that some patterns aren’t a straightforward fit for traditional components.</span></span>

<span key="a06323c1e0534eb48f8cee51e240c741"><span offset-key="a06323c1e0534eb48f8cee51e240c741:0">For example, say you have a </span>`CommentList`<span offset-key="a06323c1e0534eb48f8cee51e240c741:2"> component that subscribes to an external data source to render a list of comments:</span></span>

1

Copied!

<span key="14c80c0903b94e2ea0154f3f2228fb19">`CommentList`<span offset-key="14c80c0903b94e2ea0154f3f2228fb19:1"> and </span>`BlogPost`<span offset-key="14c80c0903b94e2ea0154f3f2228fb19:3"> aren’t identical — they call different methods on </span>`DataSource`<span offset-key="14c80c0903b94e2ea0154f3f2228fb19:5">, and they render different output. But much of their implementation is the same:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="19b14cd178ba4f6d97e4d42b8faa7fc5"><span offset-key="19b14cd178ba4f6d97e4d42b8faa7fc5:0">On mount, add a change listener to </span>`DataSource`<span offset-key="19b14cd178ba4f6d97e4d42b8faa7fc5:2">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="219bf7a08c7841eb9f787a0d6a83795a"><span offset-key="219bf7a08c7841eb9f787a0d6a83795a:0">Inside the listener, call </span>`setState`<span offset-key="219bf7a08c7841eb9f787a0d6a83795a:2"> whenever the data source changes.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="b2e56f9ee3064135add4a66e0f184e1e"><span offset-key="b2e56f9ee3064135add4a66e0f184e1e:0">On unmount, remove the change listener.</span></span>

<span key="6dcf96c312e14486bf3bb3a455d4ca6f"><span offset-key="6dcf96c312e14486bf3bb3a455d4ca6f:0">You can imagine that in a large app, this same pattern of subscribing to </span>`DataSource`<span offset-key="6dcf96c312e14486bf3bb3a455d4ca6f:2"> and calling </span>`setState`<span offset-key="6dcf96c312e14486bf3bb3a455d4ca6f:4"> will occur over and over again. We want an abstraction that allows us to define this logic in a single place and share it across many components. This is where higher-order components excel.</span></span>

<span key="69c3d352c45f40b6af491c166051121b"><span offset-key="69c3d352c45f40b6af491c166051121b:0">We can write a function that creates components, like </span>`CommentList`<span offset-key="69c3d352c45f40b6af491c166051121b:2"> and </span>`BlogPost`<span offset-key="69c3d352c45f40b6af491c166051121b:4">, that subscribe to </span>`DataSource`<span offset-key="69c3d352c45f40b6af491c166051121b:6">. The function will accept as one of its arguments a child component that receives the subscribed data as a prop. Let’s call the function </span>`withSubscription`<span offset-key="69c3d352c45f40b6af491c166051121b:8">:</span></span>

1

<span key="7d745e75129e41d785664edb865b2afd"><span offset-key="7d745e75129e41d785664edb865b2afd:0">const CommentListWithSubscription = withSubscription(</span></span>

<span key="24936eb42ea843f8a76a795c8219c296"><span offset-key="24936eb42ea843f8a76a795c8219c296:0"> CommentList,</span></span>

<span key="c93f6067596042daabbed28c14f0774b"><span offset-key="c93f6067596042daabbed28c14f0774b:0"> (DataSource) => DataSource.getComments()</span></span>

4

<span key="2c9bae70d3ac42da800f9d23a64b0cbc"><span offset-key="2c9bae70d3ac42da800f9d23a64b0cbc:0">);</span></span>

<span key="2f27536391794f6ea357d1a5506c85fd"><span offset-key="2f27536391794f6ea357d1a5506c85fd:0">The first parameter is the wrapped component. The second parameter retrieves the data we’re interested in, given a </span>`DataSource`<span offset-key="2f27536391794f6ea357d1a5506c85fd:2"> and the current props.</span></span>

<span key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06"><span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:0">When </span>`CommentListWithSubscription`<span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:2"> and </span>`BlogPostWithSubscription`<span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:4"> are rendered, </span>`CommentList`<span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:6"> and </span>`BlogPost`<span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:8"> will be passed a </span>`data`<span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:10"> prop with the most current data retrieved from </span>`DataSource`<span offset-key="41f1a512adb0499880c47bfc36591c06:12">:</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="35fa752947de49158f96400709bdf38e"><span offset-key="35fa752947de49158f96400709bdf38e:0">Note that a HOC doesn’t modify the input component, nor does it use inheritance to copy its behavior. Rather, a HOC </span>*composes*<span offset-key="35fa752947de49158f96400709bdf38e:2"> the original component by </span>*wrapping*<span offset-key="35fa752947de49158f96400709bdf38e:4"> it in a container component. A HOC is a pure function with zero side-effects.</span></span>

<span key="b0b7013f8b0e4464b518350144f195f8"><span offset-key="b0b7013f8b0e4464b518350144f195f8:0">And that’s it! The wrapped component receives all the props of the container, along with a new prop, </span>`data`<span offset-key="b0b7013f8b0e4464b518350144f195f8:2">, which it uses to render its output. The HOC isn’t concerned with how or why the data is used, and the wrapped component isn’t concerned with where the data came from.</span></span>

<span key="c01a996add0e4a2cb8dc5dae8c3adfd9"><span offset-key="c01a996add0e4a2cb8dc5dae8c3adfd9:0">Because </span>`withSubscription`<span offset-key="c01a996add0e4a2cb8dc5dae8c3adfd9:2"> is a normal function, you can add as many or as few arguments as you like. For example, you may want to make the name of the </span>`data`<span offset-key="c01a996add0e4a2cb8dc5dae8c3adfd9:4"> prop configurable, to further isolate the HOC from the wrapped component. Or you could accept an argument that configures </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="c01a996add0e4a2cb8dc5dae8c3adfd9:6">, or one that configures the data source. These are all possible because the HOC has full control over how the component is defined.</span></span>

<span key="bf4170c416f24fc78e8323f4f7480078"><span offset-key="bf4170c416f24fc78e8323f4f7480078:0">Like components, the contract between </span>`withSubscription`<span offset-key="bf4170c416f24fc78e8323f4f7480078:2"> and the wrapped component is entirely props-based. This makes it easy to swap one HOC for a different one, as long as they provide the same props to the wrapped component. This may be useful if you change data-fetching libraries, for example.</span></span>

# 

<span key="939e7255187247b9be123a30a2f9e80b"><span offset-key="939e7255187247b9be123a30a2f9e80b:0">Don’t Mutate the Original Component. Use Composition.</span></span>

<span key="b9690675d3a845d7805714b7d160fa7f"><span offset-key="b9690675d3a845d7805714b7d160fa7f:0">Resist the temptation to modify a component’s prototype (or otherwise mutate it) inside a HOC.</span></span>

1

<span key="51c730f3a5ba4d8aae108f3ea172580e"><span offset-key="51c730f3a5ba4d8aae108f3ea172580e:0">function logProps(InputComponent) {</span></span>

3

<span key="1672dba7e34f4cf9a1b80e27f8b8927e"><span offset-key="1672dba7e34f4cf9a1b80e27f8b8927e:0"> console.log('Current props: ', this.props);</span></span>

<span key="92e57a59cca24a188b2b12f993e7b08b"><span offset-key="92e57a59cca24a188b2b12f993e7b08b:0">// EnhancedComponent will log whenever props are received</span></span>

12

Copied!

<span key="b6a8ec71583c4d188dcb0bd2b5e31b75"><span offset-key="b6a8ec71583c4d188dcb0bd2b5e31b75:0">There are a few problems with this. One is that the input component cannot be reused separately from the enhanced component. More crucially, if you apply another HOC to </span>`EnhancedComponent`<span offset-key="b6a8ec71583c4d188dcb0bd2b5e31b75:2"> that </span>*also*<span offset-key="b6a8ec71583c4d188dcb0bd2b5e31b75:4"> mutates </span>`componentDidUpdate`<span offset-key="b6a8ec71583c4d188dcb0bd2b5e31b75:6">, the first HOC’s functionality will be overridden! This HOC also won’t work with function components, which do not have lifecycle methods.</span></span>

<span key="c9bccd7b2d904f5ab1ff232bfbd6c9c1"><span offset-key="c9bccd7b2d904f5ab1ff232bfbd6c9c1:0">Mutating HOCs are a leaky abstraction—the consumer must know how they are implemented in order to avoid conflicts with other HOCs.</span></span>

<span key="579262f90774470daa49dbdf0b0b7c7b"><span offset-key="579262f90774470daa49dbdf0b0b7c7b:0">Instead of mutation, HOCs should use composition, by wrapping the input component in a container component:</span></span>

1

<span key="ea136d4b9b824969b6c7cd3b1c94e4dc"><span offset-key="ea136d4b9b824969b6c7cd3b1c94e4dc:0">function logProps(WrappedComponent) {</span></span>

2

<span key="2a808d2e9ae041e38f5b65f9ca7be50b"><span offset-key="2a808d2e9ae041e38f5b65f9ca7be50b:0"> return class extends React.Component {</span></span>

3

4

<span key="a7a201b47a0b44049d264b06420f17da"><span offset-key="a7a201b47a0b44049d264b06420f17da:0"> console.log('Current props: ', this.props);</span></span>

5

<span key="42b3f2188c68430183dcaacc11178509"><span offset-key="42b3f2188c68430183dcaacc11178509:0"> console.log('Previous props: ', prevProps);</span></span>

6

<span key="c2a5c687beb9490c80dd43fc1c7b9d50"><span offset-key="c2a5c687beb9490c80dd43fc1c7b9d50:0"> }</span></span>

<span key="a3ee089ef8ee4ead9be2d77b07984a0c"><span offset-key="a3ee089ef8ee4ead9be2d77b07984a0c:0"> // Wraps the input component in a container, without mutating it. Good!</span></span>

9

<span key="08977016d32843efa119535f10044cc6"><span offset-key="08977016d32843efa119535f10044cc6:0"> return &lt;WrappedComponent {...this.props} />;</span></span>

10

<span key="dc3ef9bb23cb4ff1a61c7e9df56ffc8e"><span offset-key="dc3ef9bb23cb4ff1a61c7e9df56ffc8e:0"> }</span></span>
