# 

<span key="04d733db062845378733c54018c29f49"><span offset-key="04d733db062845378733c54018c29f49:0">Props in JSX</span></span>

<span key="8a129381f2e74d2bba2bd74c880aa5f7"><span offset-key="8a129381f2e74d2bba2bd74c880aa5f7:0">There are several different ways to specify props in JSX.</span></span>

# 

<span key="3e60a966a7294c77b647baf1af920b7a"><span offset-key="3e60a966a7294c77b647baf1af920b7a:0">JavaScript Expressions as Props</span></span>

<span key="bc4e0f23acd24ad89728256d84907cd7"><span offset-key="bc4e0f23acd24ad89728256d84907cd7:0">You can pass any JavaScript expression as a prop, by surrounding it with </span>`{}`<span offset-key="bc4e0f23acd24ad89728256d84907cd7:2">. For example, in this JSX:</span></span>

<span key="535984eac21c458b969f1328d55129fc">`<MyComponent foo={1 + 2 + 3 + 4} />`</span>

<span key="44384c3a0878498381293fff0ac590d0"><span offset-key="44384c3a0878498381293fff0ac590d0:0">For </span>`MyComponent`<span offset-key="44384c3a0878498381293fff0ac590d0:2">, the value of </span>`props.foo`<span offset-key="44384c3a0878498381293fff0ac590d0:4"> will be </span>`10`<span offset-key="44384c3a0878498381293fff0ac590d0:6"> because the expression </span>`1 + 2 + 3 + 4`<span offset-key="44384c3a0878498381293fff0ac590d0:8"> gets evaluated.</span></span>

<span key="ad7de07f572e425ca8f4150b4e9d6178">`if`<span offset-key="ad7de07f572e425ca8f4150b4e9d6178:1"> statements and </span>`for`<span offset-key="ad7de07f572e425ca8f4150b4e9d6178:3"> loops are not expressions in JavaScript, so they can’t be used in JSX directly. Instead, you can put these in the surrounding code. For example:</span></span>

1

<span key="015041134c8e485db019b115e34b9d15"><span offset-key="015041134c8e485db019b115e34b9d15:0">function NumberDescriber(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="e49e911c0fc54a9494e25295478ed72e"><span offset-key="e49e911c0fc54a9494e25295478ed72e:0"> let description;</span></span>

3

<span key="cc76610a233a48759b9ab4990b238a3f"><span offset-key="cc76610a233a48759b9ab4990b238a3f:0"> if (props.number % 2 == 0) { description = &lt;strong>even&lt;/strong>; } else { description = &lt;i>odd&lt;/i>; } return &lt;div>{props.number} is an {description} number&lt;/div>;</span></span>

4

<span key="c63302ec0bcf4c54841c2b5e33ac34f5"><span offset-key="c63302ec0bcf4c54841c2b5e33ac34f5:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="93c35a9ef27e4dd1805ece1344e2717f"><span offset-key="93c35a9ef27e4dd1805ece1344e2717f:0">You can learn more about </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/conditional-rendering.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4e0bf0edb6ba459f87eae74f5b3585a8" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="c390b5972cac4a119e37d1157606f32b"><span data-offset-key="c390b5972cac4a119e37d1157606f32b:0">conditional rendering</span></span></span></a><span key="ac83b343ec4a457388e17df33b025a2c"><span offset-key="ac83b343ec4a457388e17df33b025a2c:0"> and </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/lists-and-keys.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="5ec37b1349e943bab34c7ab0ff06d72c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="96f436f582084671af9529258e0e21da"><span data-offset-key="96f436f582084671af9529258e0e21da:0">loops</span></span></span></a><span key="a7adb44dd0de4a0b812a54c9d1001a58"><span offset-key="a7adb44dd0de4a0b812a54c9d1001a58:0"> in the corresponding sections.</span></span>

# 

<span key="42621930a9324d00a5e3fa97d4e8efd5"><span offset-key="42621930a9324d00a5e3fa97d4e8efd5:0">String Literals</span></span>

<span key="715e646c11474ce2a42a65f75a11e59d"><span offset-key="715e646c11474ce2a42a65f75a11e59d:0">You can pass a string literal as a prop. These two JSX expressions are equivalent:</span></span>

<span key="6aba374892b142d89b334d30b0d6572e">`<MyComponent message="hello world" /><MyComponent message={'hello world'} />`</span>

<span key="0fe03009c86641e3b9d7c989a65b6c8a"><span offset-key="0fe03009c86641e3b9d7c989a65b6c8a:0">When you pass a string literal, its value is HTML-unescaped. So these two JSX expressions are equivalent:</span></span>

<span key="515ccc1091814a67872735dda04d038a">`<MyComponent message="&lt;3" /><MyComponent message={'<3'} />`</span>

<span key="3cea1ad40dde45bba7688c0dc27f1e1a"><span offset-key="3cea1ad40dde45bba7688c0dc27f1e1a:0">This behavior is usually not relevant. It’s only mentioned here for completeness.</span></span>

# 

<span key="cf342ae0220d46b485ff74cc2e016a14"><span offset-key="cf342ae0220d46b485ff74cc2e016a14:0">Props Default to “True”</span></span>

<span key="8f284c2a9bec4307b3fe4fd44d24e9e1"><span offset-key="8f284c2a9bec4307b3fe4fd44d24e9e1:0">If you pass no value for a prop, it defaults to </span>`true`<span offset-key="8f284c2a9bec4307b3fe4fd44d24e9e1:2">. These two JSX expressions are equivalent:</span></span>

<span key="78d626885d8749f8a929e43dffec5778">`<MyTextBox autocomplete /><MyTextBox autocomplete={true} />`</span>

<span key="5f01d409e9364726999607229276e45e"><span offset-key="5f01d409e9364726999607229276e45e:0">In general, we don’t recommend </span>*not*<span offset-key="5f01d409e9364726999607229276e45e:2"> passing a value for a prop, because it can be confused with the </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Object_initializer#New_notations_in_ECMAScript_2015" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="499e689e08df4eae9fe571488f7808c0" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="1d82b5659a6b48bf90a8a7f16c3fef2d"><span data-offset-key="1d82b5659a6b48bf90a8a7f16c3fef2d:0">ES6 object shorthand</span></span></span></a><span key="6d75d8702f7f46bdbd2b9258bb74f1fb"><span offset-key="6d75d8702f7f46bdbd2b9258bb74f1fb:0"> </span>`{foo}`<span offset-key="6d75d8702f7f46bdbd2b9258bb74f1fb:2"> which is short for </span>`{foo: foo}`<span offset-key="6d75d8702f7f46bdbd2b9258bb74f1fb:4"> rather than </span>`{foo: true}`<span offset-key="6d75d8702f7f46bdbd2b9258bb74f1fb:6">. This behavior is just there so that it matches the behavior of HTML.</span></span>

# 

<span key="b54b992ad928431991c0ec9b6d02af87"><span offset-key="b54b992ad928431991c0ec9b6d02af87:0">Spread Attributes</span></span>

<span key="f10ddbb966f741078003b58e4a831948"><span offset-key="f10ddbb966f741078003b58e4a831948:0">If you already have </span>`props`<span offset-key="f10ddbb966f741078003b58e4a831948:2"> as an object, and you want to pass it in JSX, you can use </span>`...`<span offset-key="f10ddbb966f741078003b58e4a831948:4"> as a “spread” operator to pass the whole props object. These two components are equivalent:</span></span>

1

<span key="f1716d81c01c47aca86dc70020322fcf"><span offset-key="f1716d81c01c47aca86dc70020322fcf:0">function App1() {</span></span>

2

<span key="daa5b2ff1e9d4a18b0b038caa050af4c"><span offset-key="daa5b2ff1e9d4a18b0b038caa050af4c:0"> return &lt;Greeting firstName="Ben" lastName="Hector" />;</span></span>

3

<span key="a4faab463c264d789e676ea566abcc5d"><span offset-key="a4faab463c264d789e676ea566abcc5d:0">}</span></span>

4

<span key="cb1d34d03e0a4bf7a18e62bb7d7ce349"><span offset-key="cb1d34d03e0a4bf7a18e62bb7d7ce349:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

5

<span key="88d8fb4d40e041e78bfc69d568c053ec"><span offset-key="88d8fb4d40e041e78bfc69d568c053ec:0">function App2() {</span></span>

6

<span key="37a436c3f8c14424879bca6250e3b57f"><span offset-key="37a436c3f8c14424879bca6250e3b57f:0"> const props = {firstName: 'Ben', lastName: 'Hector'};</span></span>

7

<span key="5d920cb0263c4a86b8af867bb8917626"><span offset-key="5d920cb0263c4a86b8af867bb8917626:0"> return &lt;Greeting {...props} />;}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3c4918164c424e249c6aed58d71a49a3"><span offset-key="3c4918164c424e249c6aed58d71a49a3:0">You can also pick specific props that your component will consume while passing all other props using the spread operator.</span></span>

1

<span key="4f5ba3493e634009b0a308b3e693ef66"><span offset-key="4f5ba3493e634009b0a308b3e693ef66:0">const Button = props => {</span></span>

2

<span key="2fd21c295cc241b68ac12918fa650d66"><span offset-key="2fd21c295cc241b68ac12918fa650d66:0"> const { kind, ...other } = props; const className = kind === "primary" ? "PrimaryButton" : "SecondaryButton";</span></span>

3

<span key="553a590d968141b183a5a2d1282ab431"><span offset-key="553a590d968141b183a5a2d1282ab431:0"> return &lt;button className={className} {...other} />;</span></span>

4

<span key="ac38c3635a2f48ea92392ee781d09f37"><span offset-key="ac38c3635a2f48ea92392ee781d09f37:0">};</span></span>

5

<span key="0ab0000912dd44488cb4b99447473bfb"><span offset-key="0ab0000912dd44488cb4b99447473bfb:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

6

<span key="e627171cec7c46e1a3620b5778db3e42"><span offset-key="e627171cec7c46e1a3620b5778db3e42:0">const App = () => {</span></span>

7

<span key="543bc2f5eb3b4b9db9c94ede371f02ed"><span offset-key="543bc2f5eb3b4b9db9c94ede371f02ed:0"> return (</span></span>

8

<span key="840654d55ed84443980876200acfca6e"><span offset-key="840654d55ed84443980876200acfca6e:0"> &lt;div> &lt;Button kind="primary" onClick={() => console.log("clicked!")}> Hello World!</span></span>

9

<span key="817d31644ecf40dbba345918326f1776"><span offset-key="817d31644ecf40dbba345918326f1776:0"> &lt;/Button> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

10

<span key="066875c2e98043c8bbe0bd1eb7efa370"><span offset-key="066875c2e98043c8bbe0bd1eb7efa370:0">};</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031"><span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:0">In the example above, the </span>`kind`<span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:2"> prop is safely consumed and </span>*is not*<span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:4"> passed on to the </span>`<button>`<span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:6"> element in the DOM. All other props are passed via the </span>`...other`<span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:8"> object making this component really flexible. You can see that it passes an </span>`onClick`<span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:10"> and </span>`children`<span offset-key="ae44d3d5dd3249c2a0fc8f4492c55031:12"> props.</span></span>

<span key="c2de3a17f543465a8b4a4294f20e0421"><span offset-key="c2de3a17f543465a8b4a4294f20e0421:0">Spread attributes can be useful but they also make it easy to pass unnecessary props to components that don’t care about them or to pass invalid HTML attributes to the DOM. We recommend using this syntax sparingly.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6c8b50ad76be4475b12cd332c84624f9"><span offset-key="6c8b50ad76be4475b12cd332c84624f9:0">Children in JSX</span></span>

<span key="3832cd0e14d04f76a147fbfa9dfccc0e"><span offset-key="3832cd0e14d04f76a147fbfa9dfccc0e:0">In JSX expressions that contain both an opening tag and a closing tag, the content between those tags is passed as a special prop: </span>`props.children`<span offset-key="3832cd0e14d04f76a147fbfa9dfccc0e:2">. There are several different ways to pass children:</span></span>

# 

<span key="ce607b337b2d44b499ec8d1df3087768"><span offset-key="ce607b337b2d44b499ec8d1df3087768:0">String Literals</span></span>

<span key="930435f38e4d463aadaa8cea268f50a0"><span offset-key="930435f38e4d463aadaa8cea268f50a0:0">You can put a string between the opening and closing tags and </span>`props.children`<span offset-key="930435f38e4d463aadaa8cea268f50a0:2"> will just be that string. This is useful for many of the built-in HTML elements. For example:</span></span>

<span key="869b843f0ce746af8029a9c642d9f5cc">`<MyComponent>Hello world!</MyComponent>`</span>

<span key="d9ce5b6bd46241c5929d41e36c6fb868"><span offset-key="d9ce5b6bd46241c5929d41e36c6fb868:0">This is valid JSX, and </span>`props.children`<span offset-key="d9ce5b6bd46241c5929d41e36c6fb868:2"> in </span>`MyComponent`<span offset-key="d9ce5b6bd46241c5929d41e36c6fb868:4"> will simply be the string </span>`"Hello world!"`<span offset-key="d9ce5b6bd46241c5929d41e36c6fb868:6">. HTML is unescaped, so you can generally write JSX just like you would write HTML in this way:</span></span>

<span key="006265ac401a438996cb8bd4a86ec95e">`<div>This is valid HTML &amp; JSX at the same time.</div>`</span>

<span key="3dab35a76db143c1a7e799a4d2ca2a28"><span offset-key="3dab35a76db143c1a7e799a4d2ca2a28:0">JSX removes whitespace at the beginning and ending of a line. It also removes blank lines. New lines adjacent to tags are removed; new lines that occur in the middle of string literals are condensed into a single space. So these all render to the same thing:</span></span>

1

<span key="8a10c72fc16f4592ac1b6f351b8f14e2"><span offset-key="8a10c72fc16f4592ac1b6f351b8f14e2:0">&lt;div>Hello World&lt;/div>&lt;div></span></span>

2

<span key="5ae24f54eb2a463e886cec2a4c7037ce"><span offset-key="5ae24f54eb2a463e886cec2a4c7037ce:0"> Hello World</span></span>

3

<span key="5f1cdd9edac74de0a42555c66436e22a"><span offset-key="5f1cdd9edac74de0a42555c66436e22a:0">&lt;/div>&lt;div></span></span>

4

<span key="45f8245cbf2b4b2da3fffac02152c058"><span offset-key="45f8245cbf2b4b2da3fffac02152c058:0"> Hello</span></span>

5

<span key="31dd7c97b8a74fb9abc1f0ee19b8421e"><span offset-key="31dd7c97b8a74fb9abc1f0ee19b8421e:0"> World</span></span>

6

<span key="12dd9fc90e624cf4bbb00cdcbe72dea5"><span offset-key="12dd9fc90e624cf4bbb00cdcbe72dea5:0">&lt;/div>&lt;div></span></span>

7

<span key="f14a15a03276444da7fbf2c9ccccf257"><span offset-key="f14a15a03276444da7fbf2c9ccccf257:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

8

<span key="bfd2fa9e01324c5fa9a98311b7bf7227"><span offset-key="bfd2fa9e01324c5fa9a98311b7bf7227:0"> Hello World</span></span>

9

<span key="85d9356f64d4464e98538239e5f697f5"><span offset-key="85d9356f64d4464e98538239e5f697f5:0">&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="2a4493ff77a84712b22ae12d5e8522d9"><span offset-key="2a4493ff77a84712b22ae12d5e8522d9:0">JSX Children</span></span>

<span key="4072676638444e1fac2c41e593adf752"><span offset-key="4072676638444e1fac2c41e593adf752:0">You can provide more JSX elements as the children. This is useful for displaying nested components:</span></span>

1

<span key="277429cf45db4e0699966364f60ca8f9"><span offset-key="277429cf45db4e0699966364f60ca8f9:0">&lt;MyContainer></span></span>

2

<span key="b5a137d14c1740ca881e1ac15ccad852"><span offset-key="b5a137d14c1740ca881e1ac15ccad852:0"> &lt;MyFirstComponent /></span></span>

3

<span key="96276f005eb3458b82c71357d560c6b6"><span offset-key="96276f005eb3458b82c71357d560c6b6:0"> &lt;MySecondComponent /></span></span>

4

<span key="b85f799050374d65aa8361e03e879d1b"><span offset-key="b85f799050374d65aa8361e03e879d1b:0">&lt;/MyContainer></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="79ffec9a2064469fa4831cdd447ae94e"><span offset-key="79ffec9a2064469fa4831cdd447ae94e:0">You can mix together different types of children, so you can use string literals together with JSX children. This is another way in which JSX is like HTML, so that this is both valid JSX and valid HTML:</span></span>

1

<span key="e4ebebef21b64901bf33eba0b5d45224"><span offset-key="e4ebebef21b64901bf33eba0b5d45224:0">&lt;div></span></span>

2

<span key="8adb9fad4e534c4e92b12336333a0cb1"><span offset-key="8adb9fad4e534c4e92b12336333a0cb1:0"> Here is a list:</span></span>

3

<span key="b9eb38f898c24099aa3931afa555b80e"><span offset-key="b9eb38f898c24099aa3931afa555b80e:0"> &lt;ul>&lt;li>Item 1&lt;/li>&lt;li>Item 2&lt;/li>&lt;/ul>&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0d21eb5e2351454d821d20ca2189bff0"><span offset-key="0d21eb5e2351454d821d20ca2189bff0:0">A React component can also return an array of elements:</span></span>

<span key="b1eb9389e84b4f3f8077d31fbcd84c8c">`render() { // No need to wrap list items in an extra element! return [ // Don't forget the keys :) <li key="A">First item</li>, <li key="B">Second item</li>, <li key="C">Third item</li>, ]; }`</span>

# 

<span key="649aed6700e541909b95f785eb2ee4c7"><span offset-key="649aed6700e541909b95f785eb2ee4c7:0">JavaScript Expressions as Children</span></span>

<span key="5db231bed3e041cba05043dbf25a20b2"><span offset-key="5db231bed3e041cba05043dbf25a20b2:0">You can pass any JavaScript expression as children, by enclosing it within </span>`{}`<span offset-key="5db231bed3e041cba05043dbf25a20b2:2">. For example, these expressions are equivalent:</span></span>

<span key="55c7b278c33f445c83af88ad09c86186">`<MyComponent>foo</MyComponent><MyComponent>{'foo'}</MyComponent>`</span>

<span key="dd39fac84ebb4c269439a91b556b9aa1"><span offset-key="dd39fac84ebb4c269439a91b556b9aa1:0">This is often useful for rendering a list of JSX expressions of arbitrary length. For example, this renders an HTML list:</span></span>

1

<span key="5208c2f2bedb45dfabea421f08f185db"><span offset-key="5208c2f2bedb45dfabea421f08f185db:0">function Item(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="78acb73c931840709ecae062a8c6a320"><span offset-key="78acb73c931840709ecae062a8c6a320:0"> return &lt;li>{props.message}&lt;/li>;}</span></span>

3

<span key="ea25dd3a4fcf4a479849619528649fa3"><span offset-key="ea25dd3a4fcf4a479849619528649fa3:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="86906333b23c431ea8cd779e380ecdd6"><span offset-key="86906333b23c431ea8cd779e380ecdd6:0">function TodoList() {</span></span>

5

<span key="57a3e406da3f4b20bd4691cdec025f9c"><span offset-key="57a3e406da3f4b20bd4691cdec025f9c:0"> const todos = \['finish doc', 'submit pr', 'nag dan to review'\];</span></span>

6

<span key="68f7c115765941fc86cd3d95eee34715"><span offset-key="68f7c115765941fc86cd3d95eee34715:0"> return (</span></span>

7

<span key="cae5f4495fae47fbb3fd80324eb7f70d"><span offset-key="cae5f4495fae47fbb3fd80324eb7f70d:0"> &lt;ul> {todos.map((message) => &lt;Item key={message} message={message} />)} &lt;/ul>);</span></span>

8

<span key="592007655028414fbf6778c3ca9d8a3a"><span offset-key="592007655028414fbf6778c3ca9d8a3a:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d1240da549f94202b94bbb235469b018"><span offset-key="d1240da549f94202b94bbb235469b018:0">JavaScript expressions can be mixed with other types of children. This is often useful in lieu of string templates:</span></span>

1

<span key="7054aa16caca4ed9a54033f756d5320e"><span offset-key="7054aa16caca4ed9a54033f756d5320e:0">function Hello(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="7b8ad48a6249493f82141c935da67700"><span offset-key="7b8ad48a6249493f82141c935da67700:0"> return &lt;div>Hello {props.addressee}!&lt;/div>;}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="65aa669239704b98b57dedfcbe3a274e"><span offset-key="65aa669239704b98b57dedfcbe3a274e:0">Functions as Children</span></span>

<span key="939c4e61d7d943e2a7f5edd314127853"><span offset-key="939c4e61d7d943e2a7f5edd314127853:0">Normally, JavaScript expressions inserted in JSX will evaluate to a string, a React element, or a list of those things. However, </span>`props.children`<span offset-key="939c4e61d7d943e2a7f5edd314127853:2"> works just like any other prop in that it can pass any sort of data, not just the sorts that React knows how to render. For example, if you have a custom component, you could have it take a callback as </span>`props.children`<span offset-key="939c4e61d7d943e2a7f5edd314127853:4">:</span></span>

1

<span key="237de7dea3ca42beb58eaf6ecf69c5b6"><span offset-key="237de7dea3ca42beb58eaf6ecf69c5b6:0">// Calls the children callback numTimes to produce a repeated component</span></span>

2

<span key="34612b821a32414f80519e0d0bb87c99"><span offset-key="34612b821a32414f80519e0d0bb87c99:0">function Repeat(props) {</span></span>

3

<span key="9f921e89e5804b2389b30d87aedd0cab"><span offset-key="9f921e89e5804b2389b30d87aedd0cab:0"> let items = \[\];</span></span>

4

<span key="963edb0db3b848be92a1c6f40ce03bc1"><span offset-key="963edb0db3b848be92a1c6f40ce03bc1:0"> for (let i = 0; i &lt; props.numTimes; i++) { items.push(props.children(i));</span></span>

5

<span key="168f9ebac205403281b2e293b6d114d3"><span offset-key="168f9ebac205403281b2e293b6d114d3:0"> }</span></span>

6

<span key="5412b203e6f34dda9fcb44d87b6db28c"><span offset-key="5412b203e6f34dda9fcb44d87b6db28c:0"> return &lt;div>{items}&lt;/div>;</span></span>

7

<span key="15d26df6784649aba6a9cd979b51bc3d"><span offset-key="15d26df6784649aba6a9cd979b51bc3d:0">}</span></span>

8

<span key="bb2ebba0cbbc4cf8b89498b8898a9954"><span offset-key="bb2ebba0cbbc4cf8b89498b8898a9954:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

9

<span key="6dac59a9c5fb41aba93fa3232e4e058a"><span offset-key="6dac59a9c5fb41aba93fa3232e4e058a:0">function ListOfTenThings() {</span></span>

10

<span key="39df783827fe408d9f3db5c1951233f4"><span offset-key="39df783827fe408d9f3db5c1951233f4:0"> return (</span></span>

11

<span key="f9a483286dc94b28ad51abd48ca96948"><span offset-key="f9a483286dc94b28ad51abd48ca96948:0"> &lt;Repeat numTimes={10}> {(index) => &lt;div key={index}>This is item {index} in the list&lt;/div>} &lt;/Repeat>);</span></span>

12

<span key="8ae8140781eb46d3b3bdbf45759a88e5"><span offset-key="8ae8140781eb46d3b3bdbf45759a88e5:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c66352622528418da99ccf5109105697"><span offset-key="c66352622528418da99ccf5109105697:0">Children passed to a custom component can be anything, as long as that component transforms them into something React can understand before rendering. This usage is not common, but it works if you want to stretch what JSX is capable of.</span></span>

# 

<span key="c3536ae8e64c4efda51883735d9d9685"><span offset-key="c3536ae8e64c4efda51883735d9d9685:0">Booleans, Null, and Undefined Are Ignored</span></span>

<span key="692647000bd04302acfd9d98d5d77495">`false`<span offset-key="692647000bd04302acfd9d98d5d77495:1">, </span>`null`<span offset-key="692647000bd04302acfd9d98d5d77495:3">, </span>`undefined`<span offset-key="692647000bd04302acfd9d98d5d77495:5">, and </span>`true`<span offset-key="692647000bd04302acfd9d98d5d77495:7"> are valid children. They simply don’t render. These JSX expressions will all render to the same thing:</span></span>

1

<span key="3bd861d0d07d49ca83038ad397586ef2"><span offset-key="3bd861d0d07d49ca83038ad397586ef2:0">&lt;div />&lt;div>&lt;/div>&lt;div>{false}&lt;/div>&lt;div>{null}&lt;/div>&lt;div>{undefined}&lt;/div>&lt;div>{true}&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="01e26c722055412ab968c7384ad30958"><span offset-key="01e26c722055412ab968c7384ad30958:0">This can be useful to conditionally render React elements. This JSX renders the </span>`<Header />`<span offset-key="01e26c722055412ab968c7384ad30958:2"> component only if </span>`showHeader`<span offset-key="01e26c722055412ab968c7384ad30958:4"> is </span>`true`<span offset-key="01e26c722055412ab968c7384ad30958:6">:</span></span>

1

<span key="e3dd1eb6eeb74776a38bd21f6dc64506"><span offset-key="e3dd1eb6eeb74776a38bd21f6dc64506:0">&lt;div> {showHeader && &lt;Header />} &lt;Content />&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="aae4c17bd68242feb984661d95ed9ee8"><span offset-key="aae4c17bd68242feb984661d95ed9ee8:0">One caveat is that some </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Falsy" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="07ed985bb4604181bf07c237089296cd" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="a0133d70983b4e628f2611e05a9e13e7"><span data-offset-key="a0133d70983b4e628f2611e05a9e13e7:0">“falsy” values</span></span></span></a><span key="dcfe9ebed8dd41d1ad4d5a71f5023e7b"><span offset-key="dcfe9ebed8dd41d1ad4d5a71f5023e7b:0">, such as the </span>`0`<span offset-key="dcfe9ebed8dd41d1ad4d5a71f5023e7b:2"> number, are still rendered by React. For example, this code will not behave as you might expect because </span>`0`<span offset-key="dcfe9ebed8dd41d1ad4d5a71f5023e7b:4"> will be printed when </span>`props.messages`<span offset-key="dcfe9ebed8dd41d1ad4d5a71f5023e7b:6"> is an empty array:</span></span>

1

<span key="98c1b9a8a1524b83b8090474cddaaae5"><span offset-key="98c1b9a8a1524b83b8090474cddaaae5:0">&lt;div> {props.messages.length && &lt;MessageList messages={props.messages} />}</span></span>

2

<span key="19ea57638b4f4ab39d88eda251b93cff"><span offset-key="19ea57638b4f4ab39d88eda251b93cff:0">&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="af00906011fb496ebd46835497ea6897"><span offset-key="af00906011fb496ebd46835497ea6897:0">To fix this, make sure that the expression before </span>`&&`<span offset-key="af00906011fb496ebd46835497ea6897:2"> is always boolean:</span></span>

1

<span key="bdb6097b1a9e43cc8722fcc2ff604356"><span offset-key="bdb6097b1a9e43cc8722fcc2ff604356:0">&lt;div> {props.messages.length &gt; 0 && &lt;MessageList messages={props.messages} />}</span></span>

2

<span key="28fc63b673eb4e79bc937820765a92dc"><span offset-key="28fc63b673eb4e79bc937820765a92dc:0">&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="89ff68de85124132bb39fba6b4fa5b14"><span offset-key="89ff68de85124132bb39fba6b4fa5b14:0">Conversely, if you want a value like </span>`false`<span offset-key="89ff68de85124132bb39fba6b4fa5b14:2">, </span>`true`<span offset-key="89ff68de85124132bb39fba6b4fa5b14:4">, </span>`null`<span offset-key="89ff68de85124132bb39fba6b4fa5b14:6">, or </span>`undefined`<span offset-key="89ff68de85124132bb39fba6b4fa5b14:8"> to appear in the output, you have to </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String#String_conversion" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="878853176bd64443866613fb31860b56" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="a61b71348962477d9a8a31620b3c80d7"><span data-offset-key="a61b71348962477d9a8a31620b3c80d7:0">convert it to a string</span></span></span></a><span key="f3e59767fb20451686af5b9564014e61"><span offset-key="f3e59767fb20451686af5b9564014e61:0"> first:</span></span>

1

<span key="47661c509bdd469f80b8b3e0e3e49994"><span offset-key="47661c509bdd469f80b8b3e0e3e49994:0">&lt;div> My JavaScript variable is {String(myVariable)}.&lt;/div></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="67fff329620345e3819e8d0f50524457">**Optimizing Performance**</span>

# 

<span key="f77f7da14e9c4d78b801e4629087a86c"><span offset-key="f77f7da14e9c4d78b801e4629087a86c:0">Internally, React uses several clever techniques to minimize the number of costly DOM operations required to update the UI. For many applications, using React will lead to a fast user interface without doing much work to specifically optimize for performance. Nevertheless, there are several ways you can speed up your React application.</span></span>

# 

<span key="e49f678faf0a4c08aefceb4f8b854687"><span offset-key="e49f678faf0a4c08aefceb4f8b854687:0">Use the Production Build</span></span>

<span key="431a2bb1cbc44b708bef4b0c9d05b25f"><span offset-key="431a2bb1cbc44b708bef4b0c9d05b25f:0">If you’re benchmarking or experiencing performance problems in your React apps, make sure you’re testing with the minified production build.</span></span>

<span key="fa1095ca42a840088ca5dd3f6e9438c1"><span offset-key="fa1095ca42a840088ca5dd3f6e9438c1:0">By default, React includes many helpful warnings. These warnings are very useful in development. However, they make React larger and slower so you should make sure to use the production version when you deploy the app.</span></span>

<span key="131ea3f3bfe8491cbb8e0814f55c8f14"><span offset-key="131ea3f3bfe8491cbb8e0814f55c8f14:0">If you aren’t sure whether your build process is set up correctly, you can check it by installing </span></span><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/react-developer-tools/fmkadmapgofadopljbjfkapdkoienihi" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bd768975d97c4347822ff2ea34265fa2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="be668b3ab78c45b9ad97f06c3b0af1b8"><span data-offset-key="be668b3ab78c45b9ad97f06c3b0af1b8:0">React Developer Tools for Chrome</span></span></span></a><span key="d959513594284f77a1e106ddcf4701ba"><span offset-key="d959513594284f77a1e106ddcf4701ba:0">. If you visit a site with React in production mode, the icon will have a dark background:</span></span>

<span key="da2301da3e7543c59a2134bc4144e7c2"><span offset-key="da2301da3e7543c59a2134bc4144e7c2:0">https://reactjs.org/static/d0f767f80866431ccdec18f200ca58f1/0a47e/devtools-prod.png</span></span>

<span key="e6dbcf1228ff4362a76bf3250f573f5a"><span offset-key="e6dbcf1228ff4362a76bf3250f573f5a:0">If you visit a site with React in development mode, the icon will have a red background:</span></span>

<span key="73734ea2d0c942eebfde83ed2cc033d7"><span offset-key="73734ea2d0c942eebfde83ed2cc033d7:0">https://reactjs.org/static/e434ce2f7e64f63e597edf03f4465694/0a47e/devtools-dev.png</span></span>

<span key="98bc1caea2f3419f8bd466ae11828149"><span offset-key="98bc1caea2f3419f8bd466ae11828149:0">It is expected that you use the development mode when working on your app, and the production mode when deploying your app to the users.</span></span>

<span key="cbeb9c87ab33469492dba10cc9554a18"><span offset-key="cbeb9c87ab33469492dba10cc9554a18:0">You can find instructions for building your app for production below.</span></span>

# 

<span key="bbec06f241264967962c3899ff3b9927"><span offset-key="bbec06f241264967962c3899ff3b9927:0">Create React App</span></span>

<span key="04082eeb83c54e47a9cc9aa1df5ae899"><span offset-key="04082eeb83c54e47a9cc9aa1df5ae899:0">If your project is built with </span></span><a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4b6edfe733284a2786ccfb0625af401b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="3d437840b66d40929b25229857662d0d"><span data-offset-key="3d437840b66d40929b25229857662d0d:0">Create React App</span></span></span></a><span key="8c05c582d1aa4ec98eccbddcbe6b7099"><span offset-key="8c05c582d1aa4ec98eccbddcbe6b7099:0">, run:</span></span>

1

<span key="e14c33b7356d4cc298362e7f26951b8b"><span offset-key="e14c33b7356d4cc298362e7f26951b8b:0">npm run build</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="197f7ebb5aac40d5a4f8fa3ba94a9d85"><span offset-key="197f7ebb5aac40d5a4f8fa3ba94a9d85:0">This will create a production build of your app in the </span>`build/`<span offset-key="197f7ebb5aac40d5a4f8fa3ba94a9d85:2"> folder of your project.</span></span>

<span key="df66c9c7e4d34cc7906346e439a77786"><span offset-key="df66c9c7e4d34cc7906346e439a77786:0">Remember that this is only necessary before deploying to production. For normal development, use </span>`npm start`<span offset-key="df66c9c7e4d34cc7906346e439a77786:2">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="28ca1744054a4810b0ffe57dfc5fb28a"><span offset-key="28ca1744054a4810b0ffe57dfc5fb28a:0">Single-File Builds</span></span>

<span key="091a5d9ac98a441ca92f011f7beb5a34"><span offset-key="091a5d9ac98a441ca92f011f7beb5a34:0">We offer production-ready versions of React and React DOM as single files:</span></span>

1

<span key="8f649f0d87df47f8943fb16e5fd63a3f"><span offset-key="8f649f0d87df47f8943fb16e5fd63a3f:0">&lt;script src="&lt;https://unpkg.com/<a href="../../../../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html" class="__cf_email__">[email protected]</a>/umd/react.production.min.js>">&lt;/script>&lt;script src="&lt;https://unpkg.com/<a href="../../../../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html" class="__cf_email__">[email protected]</a>/umd/react-dom.production.min.js>">&lt;/script></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b84eb157fa764d888c25ac26531df6bd"><span offset-key="b84eb157fa764d888c25ac26531df6bd:0">Remember that only React files ending with </span>`.production.min.js`<span offset-key="b84eb157fa764d888c25ac26531df6bd:2"> are suitable for production.</span></span>

# 

<span key="9eba8bdf1a5a41198cef7d0993c1b650"><span offset-key="9eba8bdf1a5a41198cef7d0993c1b650:0">Brunch</span></span>

<span key="1cc09fffcb594545b48efc2ce5260464"><span offset-key="1cc09fffcb594545b48efc2ce5260464:0">For the most efficient Brunch production build, install the </span>`[terser-brunch](<https://github.com/brunch/terser-brunch>)`<span offset-key="1cc09fffcb594545b48efc2ce5260464:2"> plugin:</span></span>

1

<span key="3392fc0419f44aea9ce3c4ca39b8b24d"><span offset-key="3392fc0419f44aea9ce3c4ca39b8b24d:0"># If you use npm</span></span>

2

<span key="7f03174df67a41e5aac818d5037aa261"><span offset-key="7f03174df67a41e5aac818d5037aa261:0">npm install --save-dev terser-brunch</span></span>

3

<span key="7f946c53792e44bd97c35905b8fa3303"><span offset-key="7f946c53792e44bd97c35905b8fa3303:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="58d9a578fb27496db63c6a8ce4428d39"><span offset-key="58d9a578fb27496db63c6a8ce4428d39:0"># If you use Yarn</span></span>

5

<span key="22735334ad9d4ca283d4116a554f3f7f"><span offset-key="22735334ad9d4ca283d4116a554f3f7f:0">yarn add --dev terser-brunch</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="28cd6e070b4845bb8fbc92bdddd6fd28"><span offset-key="28cd6e070b4845bb8fbc92bdddd6fd28:0">Then, to create a production build, add the </span>`-p`<span offset-key="28cd6e070b4845bb8fbc92bdddd6fd28:2"> flag to the </span>`build`<span offset-key="28cd6e070b4845bb8fbc92bdddd6fd28:4"> command:</span></span>

1

<span key="f7d4554b3d344bd4879f7f5bc7dfbc6b"><span offset-key="f7d4554b3d344bd4879f7f5bc7dfbc6b:0">brunch build -p</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="81d45108509c43fe91384a925ddb9e55"><span offset-key="81d45108509c43fe91384a925ddb9e55:0">Remember that you only need to do this for production builds. You shouldn’t pass the </span>`-p`<span offset-key="81d45108509c43fe91384a925ddb9e55:2"> flag or apply this plugin in development, because it will hide useful React warnings and make the builds much slower.</span></span>

# 

<span key="556c791611b245ed8d1b2af245dd172d"><span offset-key="556c791611b245ed8d1b2af245dd172d:0">Browserify</span></span>

<span key="45f7e95c96474c05a43ac375e6f478c7"><span offset-key="45f7e95c96474c05a43ac375e6f478c7:0">For the most efficient Browserify production build, install a few plugins:</span></span>

1

<span key="1b3367e936e543c380f05eb4ef06ea30"><span offset-key="1b3367e936e543c380f05eb4ef06ea30:0"># If you use npm</span></span>

2

<span key="8847f28196334a7f8176b261048a5dae"><span offset-key="8847f28196334a7f8176b261048a5dae:0">npm install --save-dev envify terser uglifyify</span></span>

3

<span key="ed5f74dccdbd4e7093878769bb68d235"><span offset-key="ed5f74dccdbd4e7093878769bb68d235:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="51998c0cc4ce47cdb821ef2ce5c2a053"><span offset-key="51998c0cc4ce47cdb821ef2ce5c2a053:0"># If you use Yarn</span></span>

5

<span key="383502a68449499488e3a980c3810d99"><span offset-key="383502a68449499488e3a980c3810d99:0">yarn add --dev envify terser uglifyify</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="645b7b08a5a346ab84263a31095e5e8d"><span offset-key="645b7b08a5a346ab84263a31095e5e8d:0">To create a production build, make sure that you add these transforms </span>**(the order matters)**<span offset-key="645b7b08a5a346ab84263a31095e5e8d:2">:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="6064584380054c9fa88a3d9b6f03ef48"><span offset-key="6064584380054c9fa88a3d9b6f03ef48:0">The </span>`[envify](<https://github.com/hughsk/envify>)`<span offset-key="6064584380054c9fa88a3d9b6f03ef48:2"> transform ensures the right build environment is set. Make it global (</span>`g`<span offset-key="6064584380054c9fa88a3d9b6f03ef48:4">).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="35abd79a30a848fb9b366bc3b29d1ce3"><span offset-key="35abd79a30a848fb9b366bc3b29d1ce3:0">The </span>`[uglifyify](<https://github.com/hughsk/uglifyify>)`<span offset-key="35abd79a30a848fb9b366bc3b29d1ce3:2"> transform removes development imports. Make it global too (</span>`g`<span offset-key="35abd79a30a848fb9b366bc3b29d1ce3:4">).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="d7df4094f2dd4b4b90203e00d06b8883"><span offset-key="d7df4094f2dd4b4b90203e00d06b8883:0">Finally, the resulting bundle is piped to </span>`[terser](<https://github.com/terser-js/terser>)`<span offset-key="d7df4094f2dd4b4b90203e00d06b8883:2"> for mangling (</span></span><a href="https://github.com/hughsk/uglifyify#motivationusage" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="51c8ef3621884d8398e77bce27cd3b52" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="32ad9b2240d84e2eb9a84328b9aaf614"><span data-offset-key="32ad9b2240d84e2eb9a84328b9aaf614:0">read why</span></span></span></a><span key="337f454364594e6caac4d8a8438be476"><span offset-key="337f454364594e6caac4d8a8438be476:0">).</span></span>

<span key="d4f4ff7b6be3481f879b54df4a4d80de"><span offset-key="d4f4ff7b6be3481f879b54df4a4d80de:0">For example:</span></span>

1

<span key="9d4990c3f0d34ba39c29fe57e5ee13fc"><span offset-key="9d4990c3f0d34ba39c29fe57e5ee13fc:0">browserify ./index.js \\\\</span></span>

2

<span key="18e42a7305404d0dbe98bc1bc71ce42d"><span offset-key="18e42a7305404d0dbe98bc1bc71ce42d:0"> -g \[ envify --NODE\_ENV production \] \\\\</span></span>

3

<span key="c505c14f912d473cba0a13e0e4175514"><span offset-key="c505c14f912d473cba0a13e0e4175514:0"> -g uglifyify \\\\</span></span>

4

<span key="76ee89e2a6454e7c90a2297dba6647ed"><span offset-key="76ee89e2a6454e7c90a2297dba6647ed:0"> | terser --compress --mangle &gt; ./bundle.js</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4cb51fd6bdf84f48a61d09a71b3b4b4e"><span offset-key="4cb51fd6bdf84f48a61d09a71b3b4b4e:0">Remember that you only need to do this for production builds. You shouldn’t apply these plugins in development because they will hide useful React warnings, and make the builds much slower.</span></span>

<span key="d1443ee8a5e7406aa8ee0586bcf6f7f2"><span offset-key="d1443ee8a5e7406aa8ee0586bcf6f7f2:0"># If you use npm</span></span>

<span key="1039b57afed64d5d967ea30c09ca0f83"><span offset-key="1039b57afed64d5d967ea30c09ca0f83:0">yarn add --dev rollup-plugin-commonjs rollup-plugin-replace rollup-plugin-terser</span></span>

<span key="2518d353ae77486893ffb2504844d920"><span offset-key="2518d353ae77486893ffb2504844d920:0">To create a production build, make sure that you add these plugins </span>**(the order matters)**<span offset-key="2518d353ae77486893ffb2504844d920:2">:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="86fff56f429b45719ba165058928ab1d"><span offset-key="86fff56f429b45719ba165058928ab1d:0">The </span>`[replace](<https://github.com/rollup/rollup-plugin-replace>)`<span offset-key="86fff56f429b45719ba165058928ab1d:2"> plugin ensures the right build environment is set.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="2f92f1cc6ec44e71809a71a7be8300a7"><span offset-key="2f92f1cc6ec44e71809a71a7be8300a7:0">The </span>`[commonjs](<https://github.com/rollup/rollup-plugin-commonjs>)`<span offset-key="2f92f1cc6ec44e71809a71a7be8300a7:2"> plugin provides support for CommonJS in Rollup.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="aa28c2f67c97405186895283b928c2a0"><span offset-key="aa28c2f67c97405186895283b928c2a0:0">The </span>`[terser](<https://github.com/TrySound/rollup-plugin-terser>)`<span offset-key="aa28c2f67c97405186895283b928c2a0:2"> plugin compresses and mangles the final bundle.</span></span>

1

<span key="f8cd4f326ce04afeb78e8fac58da10b4"><span offset-key="f8cd4f326ce04afeb78e8fac58da10b4:0">plugins: \[</span></span>

4

<span key="d3b8125a964946f0985cc6f2d9534919"><span offset-key="d3b8125a964946f0985cc6f2d9534919:0"> 'process.env.NODE\_ENV': JSON.stringify('production')</span></span>

<span key="e3ea4d35a8824a309d689635173101f0"><span offset-key="e3ea4d35a8824a309d689635173101f0:0">For a complete setup example </span></span><a href="https://www.notion.so/cb14f4bc0670c47d00d191565be36bf0" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a662e9988cec44e8be6a8024f11b124e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="d7be6ea9116e47cab31e2caaf4d9d3f5"><span data-offset-key="d7be6ea9116e47cab31e2caaf4d9d3f5:0">see this gist</span></span></span></a><span key="fededdf8dec74c2294b21ee2400596fd"><span offset-key="fededdf8dec74c2294b21ee2400596fd:0">.</span></span>

<span key="18b2e675931d4f008e61cf119ce2f5d6"><span offset-key="18b2e675931d4f008e61cf119ce2f5d6:0">Remember that you only need to do this for production builds. # 

<span key="a924a664f1b741d9ad527048539c44f3"><span offset-key="a924a664f1b741d9ad527048539c44f3:0">webpack</span></span>

> <span key="86ea0465f2874f2db8bece68707815e6"><span offset-key="86ea0465f2874f2db8bece68707815e6:0">Note:If you’re using Create React App, please follow the instructions above.This section is only relevant if you configure webpack directly.</span></span>

<span key="c4802d9e3f33450a86696804d11fed4f"><span offset-key="c4802d9e3f33450a86696804d11fed4f:0">Webpack v4+ will minify your code by default in production mode.</span></span>

1

<span key="82be4f07506445f581cbab8857a80fbc"><span offset-key="82be4f07506445f581cbab8857a80fbc:0">const TerserPlugin = require('terser-webpack-plugin');</span></span>

2

<span key="bfdf34834bd8487fbb8b288dc1281304"><span offset-key="bfdf34834bd8487fbb8b288dc1281304:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

3

<span key="f86c7d96113847b5a30f4cec7578e597"><span offset-key="f86c7d96113847b5a30f4cec7578e597:0">module.exports = {</span></span>

4

<span key="78990693dd3d40d88a62d470983d3ac2"><span offset-key="78990693dd3d40d88a62d470983d3ac2:0"> mode: 'production',</span></span>

5

<span key="74680286015b47dd8644e79e05dfe1c9"><span offset-key="74680286015b47dd8644e79e05dfe1c9:0"> optimization: {</span></span>

6

<span key="e1a368f9564540af97897f0dda815b93"><span offset-key="e1a368f9564540af97897f0dda815b93:0"> minimizer: \[new TerserPlugin({ /\* additional options here \*/ })\],</span></span>

7

<span key="285e6b53d3854bd4b856ea07ea1b8632"><span offset-key="285e6b53d3854bd4b856ea07ea1b8632:0"> },</span></span>

<span key="12da29cb0e7649b4a27b69496f382afc"><span offset-key="12da29cb0e7649b4a27b69496f382afc:0">You can learn more about this in </span></span><a href="https://webpack.js.org/guides/production/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="45e3ae2b1d80463d99b49bb7ce44b8a5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="4371a724f2d442d1bea2758ffff20742"><span data-offset-key="4371a724f2d442d1bea2758ffff20742:0">webpack documentation</span></span></span></a><span key="66ff964f8ddd4b1b9ea8facd8e41d0b3"><span offset-key="66ff964f8ddd4b1b9ea8facd8e41d0b3:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="8ee582b04c17472a89e32f0ac881faf0"><span offset-key="8ee582b04c17472a89e32f0ac881faf0:0">Profiling Components with the DevTools Profiler</span></span>

<span key="9e665a5c728f40a5aa3bdfab8d764e56">`react-dom`<span offset-key="9e665a5c728f40a5aa3bdfab8d764e56:1"> 16.5+ and </span>`react-native`<span offset-key="9e665a5c728f40a5aa3bdfab8d764e56:3"> 0.57+ provide enhanced profiling capabilities in DEV mode with the React DevTools Profiler. An overview of the Profiler can be found in the blog post </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/blog/2018/09/10/introducing-the-react-profiler.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="99253ed2334549bfaff11e0054f383eb" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="9c3d6d60fb8e46e28bdbf3985e9fef16"><span data-offset-key="9c3d6d60fb8e46e28bdbf3985e9fef16:0">“Introducing the React Profiler”</span></span></span></a><span key="5e8c8fb1dfa646a58a8ddefaa131c418"><span offset-key="5e8c8fb1dfa646a58a8ddefaa131c418:0">. A video walkthrough of the profiler is also </span></span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nySib7ipZdk" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="1c40f6c9e1654a12b00e7e89afca450c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="3a5c42a5227b4c51bf6390b8678f5295"><span data-offset-key="3a5c42a5227b4c51bf6390b8678f5295:0">available on YouTube</span></span></span></a><span key="4d6cd21129d04e7eb007c54e96598527"><span offset-key="4d6cd21129d04e7eb007c54e96598527:0">.</span></span>

<span key="7e06fa45ec5a411ea152ffa0b84e3f65"><span offset-key="7e06fa45ec5a411ea152ffa0b84e3f65:0">If you haven’t yet installed the React DevTools, you can find them here:</span></span>

    <span key="1775e30227e64329a9750000431fc22c"><span offset-key="1775e30227e64329a9750000431fc22c:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://addons.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/addon/react-devtools/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="de44d09111f4421aa759411b72611f80" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="3e91bdf166e94734928b9cab43fbb121"><span data-offset-key="3e91bdf166e94734928b9cab43fbb121:0">Firefox Browser Extension</span></span></span></a><span key="bbe13e52cc3741b2a0d84b5d0c44b907"><span offset-key="bbe13e52cc3741b2a0d84b5d0c44b907:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

    <span key="fd82be1c05554a57a62140b12560c7f4"><span offset-key="fd82be1c05554a57a62140b12560c7f4:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-devtools" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="372e615369e34fb8989356539534def4" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="e83543a3e8b14b1b868ba74a3aa344eb"><span data-offset-key="e83543a3e8b14b1b868ba74a3aa344eb:0">Standalone Node Package</span></span></span></a><span key="f1ffecddf110469b8f9c4cd6a473d3df"><span offset-key="f1ffecddf110469b8f9c4cd6a473d3df:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

> <span key="b17564fbe7c94fadb84a54db84beb6da"><span offset-key="b17564fbe7c94fadb84a54db84beb6da:0">NoteA production profiling bundle of react-dom is also available as react-dom/profiling. Read more about how to use this bundle at </span></span><a href="http://fb.me/react-profiling" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7a92c096bde642c78cf632beec78a40c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="6efef02ad767409182ce00aa04de85be"><span data-offset-key="6efef02ad767409182ce00aa04de85be:0">fb.me/react-profiling</span></span></span></a><span key="c2db051960ed4685bcea38398870733f"><span offset-key="c2db051960ed4685bcea38398870733f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

> <span key="723803c7893046ec9bd074b7f9c7ecd2"><span offset-key="723803c7893046ec9bd074b7f9c7ecd2:0">NoteBefore React 17, we use the standard User Timing API to profile components with the chrome performance tab. For a more detailed walkthrough, check out this article by Ben Schwarz.</span></span>

# 

<span key="b2aad4275a354d188a4f4b96e8e95de8"><span offset-key="b2aad4275a354d188a4f4b96e8e95de8:0">Virtualize Long Lists</span></span>

<span key="e5e0e55607484b408e6fb4a5dcd28979"><span offset-key="e5e0e55607484b408e6fb4a5dcd28979:0">If your application renders long lists of data (hundreds or thousands of rows), we recommend using a technique known as “windowing”. This technique only renders a small subset of your rows at any given time, and can dramatically reduce the time it takes to re-render the components as well as the number of DOM nodes created.</span></span>

<span key="b2defd24482441e083f4e6d5a48fd0df"><span offset-key="b2defd24482441e083f4e6d5a48fd0df:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://react-window.now.sh" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bc8a9845dc0a436e96f9a35cdfffaca5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="b9dc2e38a90b46cba23431d802ff4f36"><span data-offset-key="b9dc2e38a90b46cba23431d802ff4f36:0">react-window</span></span></span></a><span key="da8efaa57c3b47dcaf15a6c57be7fa12"><span offset-key="da8efaa57c3b47dcaf15a6c57be7fa12:0"> and </span></span><a href="https://bvaughn.github.io/react-virtualized/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="cb0425ce9ac247f9b6bfac7bf8d3877a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="d1ee86db424e4ee482a6e5919eb0a2c1"><span data-offset-key="d1ee86db424e4ee482a6e5919eb0a2c1:0">react-virtualized</span></span></span></a><span key="1f21606846944c4eabe5ff8e40cd1aeb"><span offset-key="1f21606846944c4eabe5ff8e40cd1aeb:0"> are popular windowing libraries. They provide several reusable components for displaying lists, grids, and tabular data. You can also create your own windowing component, like </span></span><a href="https://medium.com/@paularmstrong/twitter-lite-and-high-performance-react-progressive-web-apps-at-scale-d28a00e780a3" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="14048a5a938a42e492b8cb1a0571ca89" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="ef6e4745bc524bf1be700137405b2f16"><span data-offset-key="ef6e4745bc524bf1be700137405b2f16:0">Twitter did</span></span></span></a><span key="ac9a0d37a3514898a55137454dedcd0f"><span offset-key="ac9a0d37a3514898a55137454dedcd0f:0">, if you want something more tailored to your application’s specific use case.</span></span>

# 

<span key="b4963cdc5fac472bb73803c3269ba461"><span offset-key="b4963cdc5fac472bb73803c3269ba461:0">Avoid Reconciliation</span></span>

<span key="a4390aff068349b990c8d15fde6e5e53"><span offset-key="a4390aff068349b990c8d15fde6e5e53:0">React builds and maintains an internal representation of the rendered UI. It includes the React elements you return from your components. This representation lets React avoid creating DOM nodes and accessing existing ones beyond necessity, as that can be slower than operations on JavaScript objects. Sometimes it is referred to as a “virtual DOM”, but it works the same way on React Native.</span></span>

<span key="f1a6be798af843a4adc9dc0c2c9bc8fa"><span offset-key="f1a6be798af843a4adc9dc0c2c9bc8fa:0">When a component’s props or state change, React decides whether an actual DOM update is necessary by comparing the newly returned element with the previously rendered one. When they are not equal, React will update the DOM.</span></span>

<span key="6ce0dd0b3a03470bb286f6a9aea4f3e6"><span offset-key="6ce0dd0b3a03470bb286f6a9aea4f3e6:0">Even though React only updates the changed DOM nodes, re-rendering still takes some time. In many cases it’s not a problem, but if the slowdown is noticeable, you can speed all of this up by overriding the lifecycle function </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="6ce0dd0b3a03470bb286f6a9aea4f3e6:2">, which is triggered before the re-rendering process starts. The default implementation of this function returns </span>`true`<span offset-key="6ce0dd0b3a03470bb286f6a9aea4f3e6:4">, leaving React to perform the update:</span></span>

1

<span key="0dabb832705e48bb8d6a43ec520e063d"><span offset-key="0dabb832705e48bb8d6a43ec520e063d:0">shouldComponentUpdate(nextProps, nextState) {</span></span>

2

<span key="36807e8d16b548dfbce22e97ca6f6605"><span offset-key="36807e8d16b548dfbce22e97ca6f6605:0"> return true;</span></span>

3

<span key="2ea8da0acd2c42bf9aff504c66af8b23"><span offset-key="2ea8da0acd2c42bf9aff504c66af8b23:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e3fb16b9e58d48e6b85684be6442870e"><span offset-key="e3fb16b9e58d48e6b85684be6442870e:0">If you know that in some situations your component doesn’t need to update, you can return </span>`false`<span offset-key="e3fb16b9e58d48e6b85684be6442870e:2"> from </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="e3fb16b9e58d48e6b85684be6442870e:4"> instead, to skip the whole rendering process, including calling </span>`render()`<span offset-key="e3fb16b9e58d48e6b85684be6442870e:6"> on this component and below.</span></span>

<span key="24a1d7831017430cb6dee4c7b82e4935"><span offset-key="24a1d7831017430cb6dee4c7b82e4935:0">In most cases, instead of writing </span>`shouldComponentUpdate()`<span offset-key="24a1d7831017430cb6dee4c7b82e4935:2"> by hand, you can inherit from </span>`[React.PureComponent](<https://reactjs.org/docs/react-api.html#reactpurecomponent>)`<span offset-key="24a1d7831017430cb6dee4c7b82e4935:4">. It is equivalent to implementing </span>`shouldComponentUpdate()`<span offset-key="24a1d7831017430cb6dee4c7b82e4935:6"> with a shallow comparison of current and previous props and state.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6afba8a36ad94e7c8778c16ceb15d263"><span offset-key="6afba8a36ad94e7c8778c16ceb15d263:0">shouldComponentUpdate In Action</span></span>

<span key="bad5068b8d5d4f768e6c92f0fc507ff8"><span offset-key="bad5068b8d5d4f768e6c92f0fc507ff8:0">Here’s a subtree of components. For each one, </span>`SCU`<span offset-key="bad5068b8d5d4f768e6c92f0fc507ff8:2"> indicates what </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="bad5068b8d5d4f768e6c92f0fc507ff8:4"> returned, and </span>`vDOMEq`<span offset-key="bad5068b8d5d4f768e6c92f0fc507ff8:6"> indicates whether the rendered React elements were equivalent. Finally, the circle’s color indicates whether the component had to be reconciled or not.</span></span>

<span key="cbd692e8152142969bdf32825534e72c"><span offset-key="cbd692e8152142969bdf32825534e72c:0">https://reactjs.org/static/5ee1bdf4779af06072a17b7a0654f6db/cd039/should-component-update.png</span></span>

<span key="b513c79fd6f94f1a87b8466b49114a91"><span offset-key="b513c79fd6f94f1a87b8466b49114a91:0">Since </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="b513c79fd6f94f1a87b8466b49114a91:2"> returned </span>`false`<span offset-key="b513c79fd6f94f1a87b8466b49114a91:4"> for the subtree rooted at C2, React did not attempt to render C2, and thus didn’t even have to invoke </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="b513c79fd6f94f1a87b8466b49114a91:6"> on C4 and C5.</span></span>

<span key="82fdc8e12ece4e83b23eb3af060b82c9"><span offset-key="82fdc8e12ece4e83b23eb3af060b82c9:0">For C1 and C3, </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="82fdc8e12ece4e83b23eb3af060b82c9:2"> returned </span>`true`<span offset-key="82fdc8e12ece4e83b23eb3af060b82c9:4">, so React had to go down to the leaves and check them. For C6 </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="82fdc8e12ece4e83b23eb3af060b82c9:6"> returned </span>`true`<span offset-key="82fdc8e12ece4e83b23eb3af060b82c9:8">, and since the rendered elements weren’t equivalent React had to update the DOM.</span></span>

<span key="0f61a0ebc2ae445abde0c047a43d166a"><span offset-key="0f61a0ebc2ae445abde0c047a43d166a:0">The last interesting case is C8. React had to render this component, but since the React elements it returned were equal to the previously rendered ones, it didn’t have to update the DOM.</span></span>

<span key="529290810751408ba332ab558933483d"><span offset-key="529290810751408ba332ab558933483d:0">Note that React only had to do DOM mutations for C6, which was inevitable. For C8, it bailed out by comparing the rendered React elements, and for C2’s subtree and C7, it didn’t even have to compare the elements as we bailed out on </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="529290810751408ba332ab558933483d:2">, and </span>`render`<span offset-key="529290810751408ba332ab558933483d:4"> was not called.</span></span>

# 

<span key="06c0f50f794a433cacdc02c95a158a14"><span offset-key="06c0f50f794a433cacdc02c95a158a14:0">Examples</span></span>

<span key="014a90581f0c44d5b064735c37bdd709"><span offset-key="014a90581f0c44d5b064735c37bdd709:0">If the only way your component ever changes is when the </span>`props.color`<span offset-key="014a90581f0c44d5b064735c37bdd709:2"> or the </span>`state.count`<span offset-key="014a90581f0c44d5b064735c37bdd709:4"> variable changes, you could have </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="014a90581f0c44d5b064735c37bdd709:6"> check that:</span></span>

1

<span key="6c3aa14ed3c74ec3b06d8b58ce400b00"><span offset-key="6c3aa14ed3c74ec3b06d8b58ce400b00:0">class CounterButton extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="f3124261990f4b7e9c91d9ac79ecd6fc"><span offset-key="f3124261990f4b7e9c91d9ac79ecd6fc:0"> constructor(props) {</span></span>

3

<span key="32e4dd46bdb04c7694ca6b713ffac717"><span offset-key="32e4dd46bdb04c7694ca6b713ffac717:0"> super(props);</span></span>

4

<span key="5ddb2e84fa284d65ad9ad92e74c75127"><span offset-key="5ddb2e84fa284d65ad9ad92e74c75127:0"> this.state = {count: 1};</span></span>

5

<span key="c06d9eb29bff4f399be9207990ec6724"><span offset-key="c06d9eb29bff4f399be9207990ec6724:0"> }</span></span>

6

<span key="24996101c1414c1180d432ce0be5220c"><span offset-key="24996101c1414c1180d432ce0be5220c:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

7

<span key="f06e16d59ca149f09fbe639bfb232046"><span offset-key="f06e16d59ca149f09fbe639bfb232046:0"> shouldComponentUpdate(nextProps, nextState) {</span></span>

8

<span key="1520811300f2469ea84c603b7b462a10"><span offset-key="1520811300f2469ea84c603b7b462a10:0"> if (this.props.color !== nextProps.color) {</span></span>

9

<span key="502de1108d014af0ab3b64e251ea0ee4"><span offset-key="502de1108d014af0ab3b64e251ea0ee4:0"> return true;</span></span>

10

<span key="d3dd3abc5ca840549b4f207bf784f5ef"><span offset-key="d3dd3abc5ca840549b4f207bf784f5ef:0"> }</span></span>

11

<span key="14dc39aca7834ca2bce99963e39f7f9b"><span offset-key="14dc39aca7834ca2bce99963e39f7f9b:0"> if (this.state.count !== nextState.count) {</span></span>

12

<span key="553887ef6f2f4c2fab590fe82e3f7509"><span offset-key="553887ef6f2f4c2fab590fe82e3f7509:0"> return true;</span></span>

13

<span key="2d690233800b47f08c1a5698d9de5255"><span offset-key="2d690233800b47f08c1a5698d9de5255:0"> }</span></span>

14

<span key="67249e3fbfe84bd98be3432928923c84"><span offset-key="67249e3fbfe84bd98be3432928923c84:0"> return false;</span></span>

15

<span key="2c90cd0106c04ab78779d77ca2542b55"><span offset-key="2c90cd0106c04ab78779d77ca2542b55:0"> }</span></span>

16

<span key="669e43563f374d33a85a0de495b9db0d"><span offset-key="669e43563f374d33a85a0de495b9db0d:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

17

<span key="838d52318be24d808b6c02ee0171cc62"><span offset-key="838d52318be24d808b6c02ee0171cc62:0"> render() {</span></span>

18

<span key="cffe7c2fcfc44ed59d589aa615a45a5f"><span offset-key="cffe7c2fcfc44ed59d589aa615a45a5f:0"> return (</span></span>

19

<span key="97becd25c0b4474d9b99e31c2adf5dbc"><span offset-key="97becd25c0b4474d9b99e31c2adf5dbc:0"> &lt;button</span></span>

20

<span key="54985a39d7964c89abc70e3c7a000ee8"><span offset-key="54985a39d7964c89abc70e3c7a000ee8:0"> color={this.props.color}onClick={() => this.setState(state => ({count: state.count + 1}))}></span></span>

21

<span key="90eeab5f724843b39525b80c3800e497"><span offset-key="90eeab5f724843b39525b80c3800e497:0"> Count: {this.state.count}</span></span>

22

<span key="7f277683d31b4c21be2eb3290ac77c9b"><span offset-key="7f277683d31b4c21be2eb3290ac77c9b:0"> &lt;/button>);</span></span>

23

<span key="afcc1cffc1474f91bc69b08b47d8951f"><span offset-key="afcc1cffc1474f91bc69b08b47d8951f:0"> }</span></span>

24

<span key="39d91b88fc4b4c7089578404a655e26a"><span offset-key="39d91b88fc4b4c7089578404a655e26a:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664"><span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:0">In this code, </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:2"> is just checking if there is any change in </span>`props.color`<span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:4"> or </span>`state.count`<span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:6">. If those values don’t change, the component doesn’t update. If your component got more complex, you could use a similar pattern of doing a “shallow comparison” between all the fields of </span>`props`<span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:8"> and </span>`state`<span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:10"> to determine if the component should update. This pattern is common enough that React provides a helper to use this logic - just inherit from </span>`React.PureComponent`<span offset-key="916906a41aa14dc98102c3e50e306664:12">. So this code is a simpler way to achieve the same thing:</span></span>

1

<span key="6324335b3ebf41cabec2ebca0a64e033"><span offset-key="6324335b3ebf41cabec2ebca0a64e033:0">class CounterButton extends React.PureComponent {</span></span>

2

<span key="b228a7f4ef6a404eb66a5f0df4cdcefb"><span offset-key="b228a7f4ef6a404eb66a5f0df4cdcefb:0"> constructor(props) {</span></span>

3

<span key="2c6044b621f84c0d9ce1b342e0b7dea4"><span offset-key="2c6044b621f84c0d9ce1b342e0b7dea4:0"> super(props);</span></span>

4

<span key="7e2e326eb01a4c6db6e493c6af2205e3"><span offset-key="7e2e326eb01a4c6db6e493c6af2205e3:0"> this.state = {count: 1};</span></span>

5

<span key="86398f0c06d449848cfdb5aedaa7af31"><span offset-key="86398f0c06d449848cfdb5aedaa7af31:0"> }</span></span>

6

<span key="2c13b12f496e4cfb8e22031310754639"><span offset-key="2c13b12f496e4cfb8e22031310754639:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

7

<span key="f1d05bd6c0d7478ba78dfd5dc8fd4759"><span offset-key="f1d05bd6c0d7478ba78dfd5dc8fd4759:0"> render() {</span></span>

8

<span key="60c081a23cd444a380489258a6e98a75"><span offset-key="60c081a23cd444a380489258a6e98a75:0"> return (</span></span>

9

<span key="1fd67bddbd4446f1b744918511b40e68"><span offset-key="1fd67bddbd4446f1b744918511b40e68:0"> &lt;button</span></span>

10

<span key="afdda59d69ea43ca935552b20ae045ac"><span offset-key="afdda59d69ea43ca935552b20ae045ac:0"> color={this.props.color}onClick={() => this.setState(state => ({count: state.count + 1}))}></span></span>

11

<span key="87f921054b32450b98b2d4994844ee16"><span offset-key="87f921054b32450b98b2d4994844ee16:0"> Count: {this.state.count}</span></span>

12

<span key="ca002a674e8043ce91e099ca57149cbc"><span offset-key="ca002a674e8043ce91e099ca57149cbc:0"> &lt;/button>);</span></span>

13

<span key="0c92b69cce5f40f283333daa7dbd8142"><span offset-key="0c92b69cce5f40f283333daa7dbd8142:0"> }</span></span>

14

<span key="cf0e665da5364d19b1627a163528ebc5"><span offset-key="cf0e665da5364d19b1627a163528ebc5:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ffb8678b83e242469a066d61d9d12983"><span offset-key="ffb8678b83e242469a066d61d9d12983:0">Most of the time, you can use </span>`React.PureComponent`<span offset-key="ffb8678b83e242469a066d61d9d12983:2"> instead of writing your own </span>`shouldComponentUpdate`<span offset-key="ffb8678b83e242469a066d61d9d12983:4">. It only does a shallow comparison, so you can’t use it if the props or state may have been mutated in a way that a shallow comparison would miss.</span></span>

<span key="09075769966e45c6bfe177a07c0b6a89"><span offset-key="09075769966e45c6bfe177a07c0b6a89:0">This can be a problem with more complex data structures. For example, let’s say you want a </span>`ListOfWords`<span offset-key="09075769966e45c6bfe177a07c0b6a89:2"> component to render a comma-separated list of words, with a parent </span>`WordAdder`<span offset-key="09075769966e45c6bfe177a07c0b6a89:4"> component that lets you click a button to add a word to the list. This code does </span>*not*<span offset-key="09075769966e45c6bfe177a07c0b6a89:6"> work correctly:</span></span>

1

3

<span key="de87a8c54ada430cb0cb948b967da130"><span offset-key="de87a8c54ada430cb0cb948b967da130:0"> return &lt;div>{this.props.words.join(',')}&lt;/div>;</span></span>

<span key="f35d07ada7f2489b8e3d647df3af9384"><span offset-key="f35d07ada7f2489b8e3d647df3af9384:0"> }</span></span>

<span key="dfd7ed62041a4c8884c8683f55d38d24"><span offset-key="dfd7ed62041a4c8884c8683f55d38d24:0">}</span></span>

<span key="9ca84183a22042a0b9f6485d2914e32b"><span offset-key="9ca84183a22042a0b9f6485d2914e32b:0"> }</span></span>

<span key="78f789b71dc74cdd9cff851de2a24680"><span offset-key="78f789b71dc74cdd9cff851de2a24680:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

23

<span key="a97c818c19a44e3facd7c4f314cdaa55"><span offset-key="a97c818c19a44e3facd7c4f314cdaa55:0"> render() {</span></span>

24

<span key="0b9926e71e2b49a891bf32b740fbd0fd"><span offset-key="0b9926e71e2b49a891bf32b740fbd0fd:0"> return (</span></span>

25

<span key="d2aebe367b8d4862a231912cd52038f9"><span offset-key="d2aebe367b8d4862a231912cd52038f9:0"> &lt;div></span></span>

28

<span key="0450375937724b7fbd2e9a5e86a3b284"><span offset-key="0450375937724b7fbd2e9a5e86a3b284:0"> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

<span key="ccb08f499d474de9ae39ee8a44b46d12"><span offset-key="ccb08f499d474de9ae39ee8a44b46d12:0"> }</span></span>
