<span key="c538b4ee093944d1ae11c831b196ea1c"><span offset-key="c538b4ee093944d1ae11c831b196ea1c:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059"><span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:0">The problem is that </span>`PureComponent`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:2"> will do a simple comparison between the old and new values of </span>`this.props.words`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:4">. Since this code mutates the </span>`words`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:6"> array in the </span>`handleClick`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:8"> method of </span>`WordAdder`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:10">, the old and new values of </span>`this.props.words`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:12"> will compare as equal, even though the actual words in the array have changed. The </span>`ListOfWords`<span offset-key="2f98f3c16de64c8a88854b3aaeb55059:14"> will thus not update even though it has new words that should be rendered.</span></span>

# 

<span key="c8699da326d742dea4bcb40b7a21de7c"><span offset-key="c8699da326d742dea4bcb40b7a21de7c:0">The Power Of Not Mutating Data</span></span>

<span key="bd72898d59f644418c3c594b748fd782"><span offset-key="bd72898d59f644418c3c594b748fd782:0">The simplest way to avoid this problem is to avoid mutating values that you are using as props or state. For example, the </span>`handleClick`<span offset-key="bd72898d59f644418c3c594b748fd782:2"> method above could be rewritten using </span>`concat`<span offset-key="bd72898d59f644418c3c594b748fd782:4"> as:</span></span>

1

<span key="d23b4f326c82423d89e9e3acd2679a1c"><span offset-key="d23b4f326c82423d89e9e3acd2679a1c:0">handleClick() {</span></span>

2

<span key="9a9f54b762304909bde5193e9eb9912f"><span offset-key="9a9f54b762304909bde5193e9eb9912f:0"> this.setState(state => ({</span></span>

3

<span key="51496cf1c8374126a911ef1e9c2be564"><span offset-key="51496cf1c8374126a911ef1e9c2be564:0"> words: state.words.concat(\['marklar'\])</span></span>

4

<span key="a72fad2bf172437491c7d8a08457137a"><span offset-key="a72fad2bf172437491c7d8a08457137a:0"> }));</span></span>

5

<span key="295f377ce4de4a909818d6f11c340500"><span offset-key="295f377ce4de4a909818d6f11c340500:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="847b14ff910c49bd82bc035fd11c8600"><span offset-key="847b14ff910c49bd82bc035fd11c8600:0">ES6 supports a </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Spread_operator" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="aa874f59b87d4cbe89bb3c3fd3c3ea6c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="389dfbab722647a9b87f967ac90d06e1"><span data-offset-key="389dfbab722647a9b87f967ac90d06e1:0">spread syntax</span></span></span></a><span key="0b22def416634068bcf27d5e5c57b566"><span offset-key="0b22def416634068bcf27d5e5c57b566:0"> for arrays which can make this easier. If you’re using Create React App, this syntax is available by default.</span></span>

1

<span key="1bb00cc4f41b4ab4a5e3503c4da2ed2a"><span offset-key="1bb00cc4f41b4ab4a5e3503c4da2ed2a:0">handleClick() {</span></span>

2

<span key="7ce0ead7cacf42b69ce8cc07abae1d0a"><span offset-key="7ce0ead7cacf42b69ce8cc07abae1d0a:0"> this.setState(state => ({</span></span>

3

<span key="9b10df4dd690405d9e41d6ed285f3715"><span offset-key="9b10df4dd690405d9e41d6ed285f3715:0"> words: \[...state.words, 'marklar'\],</span></span>

4

<span key="c1c4d979a3614d798f57421aca5cd9c8"><span offset-key="c1c4d979a3614d798f57421aca5cd9c8:0"> }));</span></span>

5

<span key="80f55e82e05147a2bb4250d7ece9c728"><span offset-key="80f55e82e05147a2bb4250d7ece9c728:0">};</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e51a0da9f85846b3a5978385e7f78580"><span offset-key="e51a0da9f85846b3a5978385e7f78580:0">You can also rewrite code that mutates objects to avoid mutation, in a similar way. For example, let’s say we have an object named </span>`colormap`<span offset-key="e51a0da9f85846b3a5978385e7f78580:2"> and we want to write a function that changes </span>`colormap.right`<span offset-key="e51a0da9f85846b3a5978385e7f78580:4"> to be </span>`'blue'`<span offset-key="e51a0da9f85846b3a5978385e7f78580:6">. We could write:</span></span>

<span key="bf0afc061a3d4cbb8d05ac4942f6d324">`function updateColorMap(colormap) { colormap.right = 'blue'; }`</span>

<span key="a97c03ffed3b4695a11e828025de1e4f"><span offset-key="a97c03ffed3b4695a11e828025de1e4f:0">To write this without mutating the original object, we can use </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/assign" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0926dee2c77e468aaf53727d194ebd9b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="c91cf1e13c36458f84aeb6b6642dc70b"><span data-offset-key="c91cf1e13c36458f84aeb6b6642dc70b:0">Object.assign</span></span></span></a><span key="af2c55d838e24610af1f1be5b98958b3"><span offset-key="af2c55d838e24610af1f1be5b98958b3:0"> method:</span></span>

1

<span key="4448b56a7caa440eb82bf6d7f77d982a"><span offset-key="4448b56a7caa440eb82bf6d7f77d982a:0">function updateColorMap(colormap) {</span></span>

2

<span key="e5b43f6fbdba4b2fa963d2c026fd1b61"><span offset-key="e5b43f6fbdba4b2fa963d2c026fd1b61:0"> return Object.assign({}, colormap, {right: 'blue'});</span></span>

3

<span key="f07f68100cee405a912a2833481fa4df"><span offset-key="f07f68100cee405a912a2833481fa4df:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="65917dc4284b4261a177a673673bc759">`updateColorMap`<span offset-key="65917dc4284b4261a177a673673bc759:1"> now returns a new object, rather than mutating the old one. </span>`Object.assign`<span offset-key="65917dc4284b4261a177a673673bc759:3"> is in ES6 and requires a polyfill.</span></span>

<span key="ece1a06fc77742ecbbc724b8c501926f"><span offset-key="ece1a06fc77742ecbbc724b8c501926f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Spread_syntax" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="40c6f67d6764475589efabaa73b0c402" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="0bbd9a24e8b94d7cba0c11df2d6aa7f6"><span data-offset-key="0bbd9a24e8b94d7cba0c11df2d6aa7f6:0">Object spread syntax</span></span></span></a><span key="914c3c27bdcb4fd6baa895bbec199989"><span offset-key="914c3c27bdcb4fd6baa895bbec199989:0"> makes it easier to update objects without mutation as well:</span></span>

1

<span key="8ac5fc2f202b410da342e1cbeff241ef"><span offset-key="8ac5fc2f202b410da342e1cbeff241ef:0">function updateColorMap(colormap) {</span></span>

2

<span key="50777f17a7664f0a8b4c6d7bcbef6bc3"><span offset-key="50777f17a7664f0a8b4c6d7bcbef6bc3:0"> return {...colormap, right: 'blue'};</span></span>

3

<span key="a350e0c486324acbb0e0267157539504"><span offset-key="a350e0c486324acbb0e0267157539504:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3e2084c5f1d0430d98ab237db098ba26"><span offset-key="3e2084c5f1d0430d98ab237db098ba26:0">This feature was added to JavaScript in ES2018.</span></span>

<span key="bbff637c2b5e43d290476b952450250d"><span offset-key="bbff637c2b5e43d290476b952450250d:0">If you’re using Create React App, both </span>`Object.assign`<span offset-key="bbff637c2b5e43d290476b952450250d:2"> and the object spread syntax are available by default.</span></span>

<span key="e0fbdc5cc36746a999294224fc33bc6b"><span offset-key="e0fbdc5cc36746a999294224fc33bc6b:0">When you deal with deeply nested objects, updating them in an immutable way can feel convoluted. If you run into this problem, check out </span></span><a href="https://github.com/mweststrate/immer" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="028d1693849e4544acfe33d43b1f8aa5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="d3f7eeb5724541f38de238f5ccc436e7"><span data-offset-key="d3f7eeb5724541f38de238f5ccc436e7:0">Immer</span></span></span></a><span key="2fb659c37897446b9d5eff701e75cf66"><span offset-key="2fb659c37897446b9d5eff701e75cf66:0"> or </span></span><a href="https://github.com/kolodny/immutability-helper" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="b941e9a9ce984d0cb74e2b7c8c379ac6" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="6adb9703b5b74a1fad3e0bb5686a89ce"><span data-offset-key="6adb9703b5b74a1fad3e0bb5686a89ce:0">immutability-helper</span></span></span></a><span key="ca880ee75a6e4f719cb587390aea19a6"><span offset-key="ca880ee75a6e4f719cb587390aea19a6:0">. These libraries let you write highly readable code without losing the benefits of immutability.</span></span>

<span key="b8213c584e074b6695565263681fb790"><span offset-key="b8213c584e074b6695565263681fb790:0">Is this page useful?</span></span><a href="https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/tree/main/content/docs/optimizing-performance.md" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="df5be7120b634bc5b8f2ea1ac0ec1040" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="1e0434df03c74f5494da8ab1aa87e1fa"><span data-offset-key="1e0434df03c74f5494da8ab1aa87e1fa:0">Edit this page</span></span></span></a><span key="4377252a07f340a9ada13416d29ac8f7"><span offset-key="4377252a07f340a9ada13416d29ac8f7:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

# 

<span key="beaa3a7adc1a4556b4f50d5ad68563f7">**Render Props**</span>

# 

<span key="cd90783df0cd4d43864b1a0c2752d34d"><span offset-key="cd90783df0cd4d43864b1a0c2752d34d:0">The term </span></span><a href="https://cdb.reacttraining.com/use-a-render-prop-50de598f11ce" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="fa9b5b589f854e8ab7f739a6e57028ab" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="bdb71aeaae554deeb4c1b225d1224306"><span data-offset-key="bdb71aeaae554deeb4c1b225d1224306:0">“render prop”</span></span></span></a><span key="b8d82585b75f434892b34148b50d3bb2"><span offset-key="b8d82585b75f434892b34148b50d3bb2:0"> refers to a technique for sharing code between React components using a prop whose value is a function.</span></span>

<span key="162d756aa2b943018bc4e64afa1a4bfb"><span offset-key="162d756aa2b943018bc4e64afa1a4bfb:0">A component with a render prop takes a function that returns a React element and calls it instead of implementing its own render logic.</span></span>

1

<span key="22da3764fa344d3690b5f4a8b5f65f54"><span offset-key="22da3764fa344d3690b5f4a8b5f65f54:0">&lt;DataProvider render={data => (</span></span>

2

<span key="f0ce77f0a7d64d9d8619f9c290f2340d"><span offset-key="f0ce77f0a7d64d9d8619f9c290f2340d:0"> &lt;h1>Hello {data.target}&lt;/h1>)}/></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1b5563fd239844d6949a42a9d1652a22"><span offset-key="1b5563fd239844d6949a42a9d1652a22:0">Libraries that use render props include </span></span><a href="https://reacttraining.com/react-router/web/api/Route/render-func" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="cf88be6e314c471791d855517be383ea" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="1bd00dd0abdd4e4b89054cf232536d75"><span data-offset-key="1bd00dd0abdd4e4b89054cf232536d75:0">React Router</span></span></span></a><span key="938ba216a05d49568057d9a78049ed1a"><span offset-key="938ba216a05d49568057d9a78049ed1a:0">, </span></span><a href="https://github.com/paypal/downshift" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f263e5b908404eddab4d9091b75b9b0b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="8524282d7ee1463682edf7dabd437ca0"><span data-offset-key="8524282d7ee1463682edf7dabd437ca0:0">Downshift</span></span></span></a><span key="ab315dbe176f4aed949dec5a25244594"><span offset-key="ab315dbe176f4aed949dec5a25244594:0"> and </span></span><a href="https://github.com/jaredpalmer/formik" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6bb23c10627d46199ae3856da95573b5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="d6f6543aba61465bb6f2665118194e6d"><span data-offset-key="d6f6543aba61465bb6f2665118194e6d:0">Formik</span></span></span></a><span key="9b37b3d26371408abae2830c6a0ede72"><span offset-key="9b37b3d26371408abae2830c6a0ede72:0">.</span></span>

<span key="df649a9dbd274cc58797dec272ee7d92"><span offset-key="df649a9dbd274cc58797dec272ee7d92:0">In this document, we’ll discuss why render props are useful, and how to write your own.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6b0bb7fd9bbe473a8a0bc406a12073d8"><span offset-key="6b0bb7fd9bbe473a8a0bc406a12073d8:0">Use Render Props for Cross-Cutting Concerns</span></span>

<span key="cfc7f80c0f9a4a4395e91200bbcce34f"><span offset-key="cfc7f80c0f9a4a4395e91200bbcce34f:0">Components are the primary unit of code reuse in React, but it’s not always obvious how to share the state or behavior that one component encapsulates to other components that need that same state.</span></span>

<span key="beaaf53a85894d88aa36ff219e257161"><span offset-key="beaaf53a85894d88aa36ff219e257161:0">For example, the following component tracks the mouse position in a web app:</span></span>

<span key="1596f1aecad54aa185ba1d8e89a37eab"><span offset-key="1596f1aecad54aa185ba1d8e89a37eab:0">As the cursor moves around the screen, the component displays its (x, y) coordinates in a </span>`<p>`<span offset-key="1596f1aecad54aa185ba1d8e89a37eab:2">.</span></span>

<span key="9d888d41ae55461aa77b286b3281cffb"><span offset-key="9d888d41ae55461aa77b286b3281cffb:0">Now the question is: How can we reuse this behavior in another component? In other words, if another component needs to know about the cursor position, can we encapsulate that behavior so that we can easily share it with that component?</span></span>

<span key="2414cb77849046b39710327cdc8b2d96"><span offset-key="2414cb77849046b39710327cdc8b2d96:0">Since components are the basic unit of code reuse in React, let’s try refactoring the code a bit to use a </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="2414cb77849046b39710327cdc8b2d96:2"> component that encapsulates the behavior we need to reuse elsewhere.</span></span>

1

<span key="15c5a57f67034c4688b3063db04487c3"><span offset-key="15c5a57f67034c4688b3063db04487c3:0">// The &lt;Mouse> component encapsulates the behavior we need...</span></span>

<span key="8b9135d52e6c45c38de462d84fde4220"><span offset-key="8b9135d52e6c45c38de462d84fde4220:0">Now the </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="8b9135d52e6c45c38de462d84fde4220:2"> component encapsulates all behavior associated with listening for </span>`mousemove`<span offset-key="8b9135d52e6c45c38de462d84fde4220:4"> events and storing the (x, y) position of the cursor, but it’s not yet truly reusable.</span></span>

<span key="5a37198f5eb54ef5be6d7de89219d307"><span offset-key="5a37198f5eb54ef5be6d7de89219d307:0">For example, let’s say we have a </span>`<Cat>`<span offset-key="5a37198f5eb54ef5be6d7de89219d307:2"> component that renders the image of a cat chasing the mouse around the screen. We might use a </span>`<Cat mouse={{ x, y }}>`<span offset-key="5a37198f5eb54ef5be6d7de89219d307:4"> prop to tell the component the coordinates of the mouse so it knows where to position the image on the screen.</span></span>

<span key="a43610c839394797a10dc372076ba281"><span offset-key="a43610c839394797a10dc372076ba281:0">As a first pass, you might try rendering the </span>`<Cat>`<span offset-key="a43610c839394797a10dc372076ba281:2"> </span>*inside* `<Mouse>`*’s* `render` *method*<span offset-key="a43610c839394797a10dc372076ba281:8">, like this:</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="bc0904dc873742e5b9399c97074388e2"><span offset-key="bc0904dc873742e5b9399c97074388e2:0">This approach will work for our specific use case, but we haven’t achieved the objective of truly encapsulating the behavior in a reusable way. Now, every time we want the mouse position for a different use case, we have to create a new component (i.e. essentially another </span>`<MouseWithCat>`<span offset-key="bc0904dc873742e5b9399c97074388e2:2">) that renders something specifically for that use case.</span></span>

<span key="ce8deb5ffe1341269465ec03ab08fa38"><span offset-key="ce8deb5ffe1341269465ec03ab08fa38:0">Here’s where the render prop comes in: Instead of hard-coding a </span>`<Cat>`<span offset-key="ce8deb5ffe1341269465ec03ab08fa38:2"> inside a </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="ce8deb5ffe1341269465ec03ab08fa38:4"> component, and effectively changing its rendered output, we can provide </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="ce8deb5ffe1341269465ec03ab08fa38:6"> with a function prop that it uses to dynamically determine what to render–a render prop.</span></span>

1

<span key="dfa82366cf6f4d3db5021ecf87c65aee"><span offset-key="dfa82366cf6f4d3db5021ecf87c65aee:0">class Cat extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="d5d74fc25de24245ace6a97df22fe9dd"><span offset-key="d5d74fc25de24245ace6a97df22fe9dd:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

4

<span key="9d2d2b2a753a4d49bd8d85ca1d290346"><span offset-key="9d2d2b2a753a4d49bd8d85ca1d290346:0"> return (</span></span>

5

<span key="cd120a95eaad4890b99ecf09b30492e6"><span offset-key="cd120a95eaad4890b99ecf09b30492e6:0"> &lt;img src="/cat.jpg" style={{ position: 'absolute', left: mouse.x, top: mouse.y }} />);</span></span>

<span key="9048d004cd4b4bc0bfac01ac31cdfdb4"><span offset-key="9048d004cd4b4bc0bfac01ac31cdfdb4:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8b53c371174b48a98ceb36fd4520bf24"><span offset-key="8b53c371174b48a98ceb36fd4520bf24:0">Now, instead of effectively cloning the </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="8b53c371174b48a98ceb36fd4520bf24:2"> component and hard-coding something else in its </span>`render`<span offset-key="8b53c371174b48a98ceb36fd4520bf24:4"> method to solve for a specific use case, we provide a </span>`render`<span offset-key="8b53c371174b48a98ceb36fd4520bf24:6"> prop that </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="8b53c371174b48a98ceb36fd4520bf24:8"> can use to dynamically determine what it renders.</span></span>

<span key="c15e5e61eade4198a90daa74ad4e133f"><span offset-key="c15e5e61eade4198a90daa74ad4e133f:0">More concretely, </span>**a render prop is a function prop that a component uses to know what to render.**</span>

<span key="30778450552e487fbab0416cb48af3c0"><span offset-key="30778450552e487fbab0416cb48af3c0:0">This technique makes the behavior that we need to share extremely portable. To get that behavior, render a </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="30778450552e487fbab0416cb48af3c0:2"> with a </span>`render`<span offset-key="30778450552e487fbab0416cb48af3c0:4"> prop that tells it what to render with the current (x, y) of the cursor.</span></span>

<span key="6ede4420ab8b4dd7aa1780918f0bac57"><span offset-key="6ede4420ab8b4dd7aa1780918f0bac57:0">One interesting thing to note about render props is that you can implement most </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/higher-order-components.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="85ce0706c9574893884565630878a4c3" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="f0fcce332d19408db87278683bec5bd5"><span data-offset-key="f0fcce332d19408db87278683bec5bd5:0">higher-order components</span></span></span></a><span key="ad4abcf391ee466d81912a3d1421bf35"><span offset-key="ad4abcf391ee466d81912a3d1421bf35:0"> (HOC) using a regular component with a render prop. For example, if you would prefer to have a </span>`withMouse`<span offset-key="ad4abcf391ee466d81912a3d1421bf35:2"> HOC instead of a </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="ad4abcf391ee466d81912a3d1421bf35:4"> component, you could easily create one using a regular </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="ad4abcf391ee466d81912a3d1421bf35:6"> with a render prop:</span></span>

1

<span key="081c970dec8449939db0548e5d68aec0"><span offset-key="081c970dec8449939db0548e5d68aec0:0">// If you really want a HOC for some reason, you can easily</span></span>

2

<span key="fcc27ca7300d410bbde6a9e8731b4d6b"><span offset-key="fcc27ca7300d410bbde6a9e8731b4d6b:0">// create one using a regular component with a render prop!</span></span>

3

<span key="4f637c55fea94f448920cfbac2c8810e"><span offset-key="4f637c55fea94f448920cfbac2c8810e:0">function withMouse(Component) {</span></span>

4

<span key="3c2d363855a3468aa6e6a10cb6a1bfbf"><span offset-key="3c2d363855a3468aa6e6a10cb6a1bfbf:0"> return class extends React.Component {</span></span>

5

<span key="eeaa4be97ec743c7a05904d69059405a"><span offset-key="eeaa4be97ec743c7a05904d69059405a:0"> render() {</span></span>

6

<span key="bc10d63c3ff640c19218975c75812807"><span offset-key="bc10d63c3ff640c19218975c75812807:0"> return (</span></span>

7

<span key="a6a1490894fc4b338e0ab7808cf0e558"><span offset-key="a6a1490894fc4b338e0ab7808cf0e558:0"> &lt;Mouse render={mouse => (</span></span>

8

<span key="5ce2ae6480e949f4b1f867cfcf19836b"><span offset-key="5ce2ae6480e949f4b1f867cfcf19836b:0"> &lt;Component {...this.props} mouse={mouse} />)}/>);</span></span>

9

<span key="718652a3dd8540c9bfd5d6853c22814d"><span offset-key="718652a3dd8540c9bfd5d6853c22814d:0"> }</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5885bdd888514093b08c3e00db012b63"><span offset-key="5885bdd888514093b08c3e00db012b63:0">So using a render prop makes it possible to use either pattern.</span></span>

# 

<span key="4f9ec620f173492fb8d879b0d889d604"><span offset-key="4f9ec620f173492fb8d879b0d889d604:0">Using Props Other Than </span>`render`</span>

<span key="12cd01ecbf0349c8985deee0bd9c3098"><span offset-key="12cd01ecbf0349c8985deee0bd9c3098:0">It’s important to remember that just because the pattern is called “render props” you don’t </span>*have to use a prop named* `render` *to use this pattern*<span offset-key="12cd01ecbf0349c8985deee0bd9c3098:4">. In fact, \*</span></span><a href="https://cdb.reacttraining.com/use-a-render-prop-50de598f11ce" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7420c5b808354f2da2eb5b9ed57a45f7" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="0581911311394e1eae57c74ca24d0275"><span data-offset-key="0581911311394e1eae57c74ca24d0275:0">any* prop that is a function that a component uses to know what to render is technically a “render prop”</span></span></span></a><span key="0b0ef082467940f0b95c283f3b2fb2e6"><span offset-key="0b0ef082467940f0b95c283f3b2fb2e6:0">.</span></span>

<span key="2796d572ea5840149f95e19b22fd1ecc"><span offset-key="2796d572ea5840149f95e19b22fd1ecc:0">Although the examples above use </span>`render`<span offset-key="2796d572ea5840149f95e19b22fd1ecc:2">, we could just as easily use the </span>`children`<span offset-key="2796d572ea5840149f95e19b22fd1ecc:4"> prop!</span></span>

1

<span key="cbeae63bb3cd433894477a57047cf250"><span offset-key="cbeae63bb3cd433894477a57047cf250:0">&lt;Mouse children={mouse => (</span></span>

2

<span key="b12b495a64414dae8396693ad52df40b"><span offset-key="b12b495a64414dae8396693ad52df40b:0"> &lt;p>The mouse position is {mouse.x}, {mouse.y}&lt;/p>)}/></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c5ef84931a3f4077b41f40a39d3a46c8"><span offset-key="c5ef84931a3f4077b41f40a39d3a46c8:0">And remember, the </span>`children`<span offset-key="c5ef84931a3f4077b41f40a39d3a46c8:2"> prop doesn’t actually need to be named in the list of “attributes” in your JSX element. Instead, you can put it directly </span>*inside*<span offset-key="c5ef84931a3f4077b41f40a39d3a46c8:4"> the element!</span></span>

1

<span key="c83ff31f7b6a491a8ca477a3c420d06c"><span offset-key="c83ff31f7b6a491a8ca477a3c420d06c:0">&lt;Mouse></span></span>

2

<span key="311c12ced365411181bebc4c3b501b55"><span offset-key="311c12ced365411181bebc4c3b501b55:0"> {mouse => (</span></span>

3

<span key="f59a4d87ea3a46d2a7e17f1c3dea4686"><span offset-key="f59a4d87ea3a46d2a7e17f1c3dea4686:0"> &lt;p>The mouse position is {mouse.x}, {mouse.y}&lt;/p>)}</span></span>

4

<span key="486b3cd4af2b429e90416fad90aa70c2"><span offset-key="486b3cd4af2b429e90416fad90aa70c2:0">&lt;/Mouse></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="15c4aec336ab4038a4e70ce71e616f90"><span offset-key="15c4aec336ab4038a4e70ce71e616f90:0">You’ll see this technique used in the </span></span><a href="https://github.com/chenglou/react-motion" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0ef8bd502ca7402590dbd081c970be10" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-30856_259-30857-237__"><span data-key="6fc62d628db1472b8d97c11faba3f5d2"><span data-offset-key="6fc62d628db1472b8d97c11faba3f5d2:0">react-motion</span></span></span></a><span key="1c20fefff0434d0a988e84eed1791a5a"><span offset-key="1c20fefff0434d0a988e84eed1791a5a:0"> API.</span></span>

<span key="4ee9b3149bd142498890fe8f3e1994b7"><span offset-key="4ee9b3149bd142498890fe8f3e1994b7:0">Since this technique is a little unusual, you’ll probably want to explicitly state that </span>`children`<span offset-key="4ee9b3149bd142498890fe8f3e1994b7:2"> should be a function in your </span>`propTypes`<span offset-key="4ee9b3149bd142498890fe8f3e1994b7:4"> when designing an API like this.</span></span>

1

<span key="e9014298be664ea780f57105342bd9cd"><span offset-key="e9014298be664ea780f57105342bd9cd:0">Mouse.propTypes = {</span></span>

2

<span key="e0034aee095e44e9bbeb3e56af414654"><span offset-key="e0034aee095e44e9bbeb3e56af414654:0"> children: PropTypes.func.isRequired</span></span>

3

<span key="b8226b8de9954cbf910354d360b62f52"><span offset-key="b8226b8de9954cbf910354d360b62f52:0">};</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="08fa6124dd0d4151823eae21007ddc16"><span offset-key="08fa6124dd0d4151823eae21007ddc16:0">Caveats</span></span>

# 

<span key="c5babb73078f476c8d50495c9ecf7d53"><span offset-key="c5babb73078f476c8d50495c9ecf7d53:0">Be careful when using Render Props with React.PureComponent</span></span>

<span key="bc44641f64fb42d8b6d987c912b59417"><span offset-key="bc44641f64fb42d8b6d987c912b59417:0">Using a render prop can negate the advantage that comes from using </span>`[React.PureComponent](<https://reactjs.org/docs/react-api.html#reactpurecomponent>)`<span offset-key="bc44641f64fb42d8b6d987c912b59417:2"> if you create the function inside a </span>`render`<span offset-key="bc44641f64fb42d8b6d987c912b59417:4"> method. This is because the shallow prop comparison will always return </span>`false`<span offset-key="bc44641f64fb42d8b6d987c912b59417:6"> for new props, and each </span>`render`<span offset-key="bc44641f64fb42d8b6d987c912b59417:8"> in this case will generate a new value for the render prop.</span></span>

<span key="9e5c537acf7d43569e5aa8239d27aafa"><span offset-key="9e5c537acf7d43569e5aa8239d27aafa:0">For example, continuing with our </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="9e5c537acf7d43569e5aa8239d27aafa:2"> component from above, if </span>`Mouse`<span offset-key="9e5c537acf7d43569e5aa8239d27aafa:4"> were to extend </span>`React.PureComponent`<span offset-key="9e5c537acf7d43569e5aa8239d27aafa:6"> instead of </span>`React.Component`<span offset-key="9e5c537acf7d43569e5aa8239d27aafa:8">, our example would look like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="aecbc769b2d94615b81aa763830f33cb"><span offset-key="aecbc769b2d94615b81aa763830f33cb:0">class Mouse extends React.PureComponent {</span></span>

2

<span key="80d4a51cbb4542a2b1a63a050c08ca06"><span offset-key="80d4a51cbb4542a2b1a63a050c08ca06:0"> // Same implementation as above...</span></span>

<span key="ee9af5f0d74c45caa031c3357ee7b3a9"><span offset-key="ee9af5f0d74c45caa031c3357ee7b3a9:0"> &lt;h1>Move the mouse around!&lt;/h1></span></span>

<span key="7b4c75d8ed0f4596a906e6ac9c0ca9e9"><span offset-key="7b4c75d8ed0f4596a906e6ac9c0ca9e9:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

11

<span key="e89127914a15499f813bcfa6d0e3dae9"><span offset-key="e89127914a15499f813bcfa6d0e3dae9:0"> {/\*</span></span>

12

<span key="7ecf69d48ec343ed881b74cc2235311d"><span offset-key="7ecf69d48ec343ed881b74cc2235311d:0"> This is bad! The value of the \`render\` prop will</span></span>

13

<span key="e60e477b1f6b47eaa0f90e4766ce063a"><span offset-key="e60e477b1f6b47eaa0f90e4766ce063a:0"> be different on each render.</span></span>

16

<span key="beafbe2db4df4b40a3f5a8124239ad75"><span offset-key="beafbe2db4df4b40a3f5a8124239ad75:0"> &lt;Cat mouse={mouse} />)}/></span></span>

17

<span key="ba826cc88509476ba96639023156e02d"><span offset-key="ba826cc88509476ba96639023156e02d:0"> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

18

<span key="9ee06678c7db499792078d8adcfab29a"><span offset-key="9ee06678c7db499792078d8adcfab29a:0"> }</span></span>

19

<span key="b235984e27ba44ed847880a6dac9dbb8"><span offset-key="b235984e27ba44ed847880a6dac9dbb8:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9a3034c6d6b94f9e9fe329a701e163d9"><span offset-key="9a3034c6d6b94f9e9fe329a701e163d9:0">In this example, each time </span>`<MouseTracker>`<span offset-key="9a3034c6d6b94f9e9fe329a701e163d9:2"> renders, it generates a new function as the value of the </span>`<Mouse render>`<span offset-key="9a3034c6d6b94f9e9fe329a701e163d9:4"> prop, thus negating the effect of </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="9a3034c6d6b94f9e9fe329a701e163d9:6"> extending </span>`React.PureComponent`<span offset-key="9a3034c6d6b94f9e9fe329a701e163d9:8"> in the first place!</span></span>

<span key="011374c85f0b4ca5babd050fff9fe87b"><span offset-key="011374c85f0b4ca5babd050fff9fe87b:0">To get around this problem, you can sometimes define the prop as an instance method, like so:</span></span>

1

<span key="8f04d59642f74f118dfa57d12599c8cb"><span offset-key="8f04d59642f74f118dfa57d12599c8cb:0">class MouseTracker extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="6d3ea68ed87c4730baa4a800511fc6b7"><span offset-key="6d3ea68ed87c4730baa4a800511fc6b7:0"> // Defined as an instance method, \`this.renderTheCat\` always</span></span>

3

<span key="cfe13d570254439488c2a4aba00459d9"><span offset-key="cfe13d570254439488c2a4aba00459d9:0"> // refers to \*same\* function when we use it in render</span></span>

4

<span key="5c079516585140759d229503ab746d48"><span offset-key="5c079516585140759d229503ab746d48:0"> renderTheCat(mouse) {</span></span>

5

<span key="7f86933985d14141b842d76db6604349"><span offset-key="7f86933985d14141b842d76db6604349:0"> return &lt;Cat mouse={mouse} />;</span></span>

6

<span key="e7d4692ecfd84044b54be8deb221e639"><span offset-key="e7d4692ecfd84044b54be8deb221e639:0"> }</span></span>

7

<span key="4ed08b9756f44905aa6e83a8ea11cdc8"><span offset-key="4ed08b9756f44905aa6e83a8ea11cdc8:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

8

<span key="2b5e706a7fcd4019b905251267b96fac"><span offset-key="2b5e706a7fcd4019b905251267b96fac:0"> render() {</span></span>

<span key="40a4f2bd2a1f4b318e91bfd53e730c26"><span offset-key="40a4f2bd2a1f4b318e91bfd53e730c26:0"> return (</span></span>

10

<span key="a0972aef50564555b38019d3a9d87f1c"><span offset-key="a0972aef50564555b38019d3a9d87f1c:0"> &lt;div></span></span>

<span key="2346b584938d47bba8a93cb5af20103d"><span offset-key="2346b584938d47bba8a93cb5af20103d:0"> &lt;h1>Move the mouse around!&lt;/h1></span></span>

<span key="0fd71aa9257545da8bfe7162f08bff75"><span offset-key="0fd71aa9257545da8bfe7162f08bff75:0"> &lt;/div>);</span></span>

<span key="c7fc82fcd36148ecad23028a24926168"><span offset-key="c7fc82fcd36148ecad23028a24926168:0">In cases where you cannot define the prop statically (e.g. because you need to close over the component’s props and/or state) </span>`<Mouse>`<span offset-key="c7fc82fcd36148ecad23028a24926168:2"> should extend </span>`React.Component`<span offset-key="c7fc82fcd36148ecad23028a24926168:4"> instead.</span></span>

Context

<a href="advanced.html#context-provides-a-way-to-pass-data-through-the-component-tree-without-having-to-pass-props-down-man" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Context provides a way to pass data through the component tree without having to pass props down manually at every level.

<a href="advanced.html#when-to-use-context" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

<a href="advanced.html#before-you-use-context" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Before You Use Context

Fragments

<a href="advanced.html#a-common-pattern-in-react-is-for-a-component-to-return-multiple-elements.-fragments-let-you-group-a" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

A common pattern in React is for a component to return multiple elements. Fragments let you group a list of children without adding extra nodes to the DOM.

<a href="advanced.html#motivation" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Higher-Order Components

<a href="advanced.html#a-higher-order-component-hoc-is-an-advanced-technique-in-react-for-reusing-component-logic.-hocs-are" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

A higher-order component (HOC) is an advanced technique in React for reusing component logic. HOCs are not part of the React API, per se. They are a pattern that emerges from React’s compositional nature.

<a href="advanced.html#use-hocs-for-cross-cutting-concerns" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Use HOCs For Cross-Cutting Concerns

<a href="advanced.html#dont-mutate-the-original-component.-use-composition." class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

<a href="advanced.html#fundamentally-jsx-just-provides-syntactic-sugar-for-the-react.createelement-component-props-...child" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Optimizing Performance

<a href="advanced.html#internally-react-uses-several-clever-techniques-to-minimize-the-number-of-costly-dom-operations-requ" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Internally, React uses several clever techniques to minimize the number of costly DOM operations required to update the UI. For many applications, using React will lead to a fast user interface without doing much work to specifically optimize for performance. Nevertheless, there are several ways you can speed up your React application.

<a href="advanced.html#use-the-production-build" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

Render Props

<a href="advanced.html#the-term-render-prop-refers-to-a-technique-for-sharing-code-between-react-components-using-a-prop-wh" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>

The term “render prop” refers to a technique for sharing code between React components using a prop whose value is a function.

<a href="advanced.html#use-render-props-for-cross-cutting-concerns" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-855088 r-dwliz8 r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-lqms97 r-dnmrzs r-iphfwy r-1guathk r-1h8ys4a r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr r-7xmw5f"></a>
